LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 

Republic of Tajikistan 
 
Targeting classification: General intervention  
Sector: Agriculture and natural resources  
Subsectors: Agriculture production, agroprocessing, and agribusiness 
Themes:  Sustainable  economic  growth,  private  sector  development,  and 
capacity development  
Subthemes:  Developing  rural  areas;  public-private  partnerships;  client 
relations, network, and partnership development 
 
Category C 

It  will  use  a 

 
The  Project  aims  to  restore  the  productivity  and  profitability  of  the  cotton 
subsector,  which  is  Tajikistan’s  main  source  of  farm  income,  agriculture 
two-tiered  strategy: 
exports,  and  rural  employment. 
(i) resolving  cotton  farm  debt  on  a  pilot  scale,  and  (ii)  improving  cotton 
market  development.  The  Project  will  operate  on  a  pilot  level  in  four 
selected cotton-producing raions (districts) of Sughd and Khatlon regions, 
the  country’s  main  cotton-producing  areas.  It will  implement  farm-by-farm 
analysis, debt resolution processes, policy reform measures, and support 
for  public  information  processes  as  well  as  provide  suitable  financing 
products and services to the restructured pilot cotton farms.  
 
Under  the  market  development  strategy,  the  Project  will  implement  the 
adoption of the internationally recognized quality standard for fiber cotton, 
the Universal Cotton Grade Standards, by (i) facilitating an internationally 
accredited  organization  to  classify  all  cotton  grown  in  the  country; 
(ii) facilitating revision of the fiber cotton export pricing formula as applied 
by  the  Tajikistan  Universal  Goods  Exchange  (TUGE)  to  reflect  quality 
differences  in  fiber  cotton;  (iii)  streamlining  the  regulatory  role  of  the 
Tajikstandard; and (iv) providing an extensive awareness program on the 
new  standard  for  all  stakeholders.  The  Project  will  also  facilitate  the 
establishment  of 
international 
standards and that will be operated by the private sector. 
 
Tajikistan’s  economic  growth  is  not  sustainable  because  it  relies  on  a 
narrow  export  base  (aluminum,  cotton,  and  hydropower)  and  remittances 
from migrant labor. In 2005, economic growth declined to 6.7%, adversely 
affected by sluggish export prices and significant cotton farm debt.  
 
The cotton subsector has been underperforming as yields and profitability 
continue to decline. At the farm level, the average yield in 2005 was only 
1.55  tons  per  hectare  (tph)—1.25  tph  short  of  the  yield  level  required  for 
cotton farms to earn reasonable profits. Labor productivity has also fallen. 
It  takes  250–350  hours  to  produce  1  ton  of  seed  cotton,  more  than  four 
times the international competitive level of 70–80 hours.  

two  bonded  warehouses 

that  meet 

 The weak subsector performance is due in part to the large and increasing 
cotton farm debt, presently estimated at $292.80 million. Debt per hectare 
ranges from $500 to over $8,000. The debt was incurred under a complex 
system of production credit from intermediaries called “investors”, and was 
supplied  largely  outside  the  formal  banking  system.  Commercial  banks 
and other financial institutions in Tajikistan have not been able to provide 
services  to  the  subsector  because  of  accumulated  farm  debts,  and  very 
limited credit resources and capacity for lending to agriculture.   
 
Sustainable  resolution  of  the  farm  debt  problem  requires  addressing  the 
symptom  (i.e.,  debt  at  the  farm  level)  as  well  as  the  underlying  cause 
(government  interference).  Full  recovery  of  the  subsector  will  need  the 
removal  of  government  interventions  that  distort  key  operations  in  the 
subsector’s value chain and make the chain ineffective.  
 
An  unprofitable  cotton  subsector  is  inextricably  linked  to  poverty.  About 
72%  of  all  the  poor  in  the  country  and  75%  of  the  extreme  poor  live  in 
Khatlon  and  Sughd.  Cotton  farmers  and  farm  workers  constitute  the  bulk 
of the rural labor force and the rural poor.  
 
There  is  an  urgent  need  to  support  the  recovery  of  the  cotton  subsector 
and  reduce  rural  poverty.  The  subsector’s  turnaround  is  the  agriculture 
sector’s  path  to  equitable-based  and  pro-poor  growth.  The  Government 
has responded to the problems afflicting the subsector by (i) developing a 
comprehensive  Cotton  Farm  Debt  Resolution  Strategy  (CFDRS)  with  a 
time-bound  and  results-based  action  plan,  and  (ii)  establishing  an 
Independent  Commission  (IC)  of  cabinet-level  officials  to  deal  with  the 
issues. The President of Tajikistan is leading the reform process and has 
agreed  with  the  international  community  to  develop  a  road  map  for  the 
sustainable  development  of  the  cotton  subsector  and  the  agriculture 
sector.  
 
The Project intends to build on the Government’s commitment to genuine 
development  change  by  addressing  the  crucial  and  immediate  concerns 
affecting  the  cotton  subsector:  (i)  accumulating  farm  debt,  (ii)  policy 
constraints  to  producer’s  incentives,  (iii)  inadequate  alternative  crop 
financing,  and  (iv)  structural  bottlenecks  that  create  market  distortions  in 
the  downstream  section  of  the  value  chain.  The  grant  component  of  the 
Project will assist the Government in addressing the farm  debt issue and 
the  structural  problems,  while  minimizing  the  negative  impact  on  the 
present  role  of  cotton  as  a  major  source  of  government  revenue,  and 
employment  and  income  to  the  vast  majority  of  the  rural  poor.  The  loan 
component of the Project will try out crop financing through the commercial 
banks, establish the joint venture with an internationally recognized cotton 
grading controller, and upgrade bonded warehouses that will be operated 
by  the  private  sector.  The  Project  is  classified  as  general  intervention 
because  addressing  these  gaps  will  enable  cotton  farms  to  reap  the 
potential  benefits  of  a  vertically  integrated  value  chain,  and  significantly 
reduce rural poverty.

The  Project’s  expected  impact  is  the  development  of  an  economically 
sustainable  cotton  subsector  in  Tajikistan’s  two  major  cotton-growing 
regions,  Khatlon  and  Sughd  (Appendix  1).  Its  outcome  is  for  the  debt-
restructured  cotton  farms  in  Vose  and  Yovon  raions  of  Khatlon  and 
Mastchoh  and  Zafarabad  raions  in  Sughd  to  sustainably  improve  their 
financial viability based on market principles. 
 
The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $15.29 million, including 
taxes and duties of $0.68 million. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will 
finance $12.00 million equivalent, comprising $5.50 million equivalent from 
Asian Development Fund (ADF) sources and $6.50 million equivalent in an 
ADF  IX  grant.  The  Government  will  finance  $1.75  million  equivalent,  and 
private sector institutions will provide $1.54 million equivalent. 
 
A  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR  3,712,000  ($5.50  million 
equivalent)  will  be  provided  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources.  The 
loan  will  have  a  32-year  term  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years,  an 
interest  rate  of  1.00%  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.50% 
thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the Financing 
Agreement. In addition, an ADF IX grant for $6.50 million will be provided 
for  (i)  the  farm  resolution  in  four  pilot  areas;  (ii)  policy  development  and 
advocacy;  (iii)  capacity  building  and  consulting  services  for  market 
development,  debt  workouts,  and  agriculture  financing  innovations;  and 
(iv) operations of the Common Center for Project Management. 
 
For measures under agriculture financing innovation, the Government will 
relend about $3 million of the ADF loan funds in U.S. dollars for a 7-year 
period,  including  a  grace  period  of  2  years,  under  subsidiary  loan 
agreements with participating commercial banks (PCBs). The interest rate 
charged will be 4%. The PCBs will assume the exchange rate and credit 
risk, and onlend to farmers in somoni using market-based interest rates.   
 
Until 30 September 2010 

 
31 March 2010 

 
The  IC  will  operate  as  the  project  steering  committee  to  provide  policy 
guidance and reform support during the Project, and facilitate coordination 
and cooperation among the major stakeholders. The Common Center for 
Project  Management  (CCfPM)  of  the  IC  will  serve  as  the  Implementing 
Agency  (IA)  for  the  farm  debt  resolution  and  the  agriculture  financing 
innovation,  while  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  will  be  the  IA  for  the  market 
development  aspects  of  the  Project.  A  project  implementation  unit  under 
the  CCfPM  will  be  jointly  established  with  the  World  Bank’s  upcoming 
Cotton Recovery and Poverty Reduction Project and it will be responsible 
for the day-to-day implementation and coordination of the Project. 
 
Executive Office of the President 

v 

 

 (QCBS) 

Procurement  of  $7  million  of  goods,  related  services,  and  civil  works  will 
be in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. 
 
The  Project  will  provide  a  total  of  1,269  person-months  of  consulting 
services,  comprising  62  person-months  of  international  consultants  and 
1,207  person-months  of  national  consultants.  Unallocated  30  person-
months  will  be  used  to  finance  consulting  services  for  policy  and  market 
development issues to be identified in the ensuing road map for the cotton 
subsector.  The  international  consultants  will  be  recruited  in  accordance 
with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The consultants will be 
selected  under  five  consulting  firm  contracts:  (i) quality-based  selection 
(QBS)  for  the  farm  debt  resolution  in  pilot  raions;  (ii)  quality-  and  cost-
based  selection 
for  market  development  measures  and 
awareness training on cotton grading; (iii) modified and/or simplified QCBS 
for  nongovernment  organizations  to  undertake  awareness  raising  during 
farm  debt  workouts,  and  develop  the  project  performance  monitoring 
system  and  gender  action  plan;  (iv)  independent  selection  for  the  center 
director; and (v) least-cost selection for the auditing firm. QBS will be used 
for  the  farm  debt  to  ensure  a  good  mix  of  highly  qualified  experts  with  a 
track  record  on  debt  resolution.  Resolving  farm  debt  quickly  is  a  high 
priority  on  the  agenda  of  the  Government,  because  of  its  adverse 
implications  on  the  sustainability  of  the  cotton  subsector  and  the 
agriculture sector in general.  
 
The  main  impact  will  be  on  cotton  farmers,  who  will  obtain  benefits  from 
farmer’s  control  over  farm  decision  making,  increased  quality  measures, 
improved  prices,  access  to  credit  from  commercial  banks,  and  a 
significantly greater proportion of the overall value of the cotton marketed. 
Greater  certainty  for  buyers  and  more  competition  among  cotton  gins  for 
the  purchase  of  fiber  cotton  produced  in  Tajikistan  will  reinforce  higher 
prices.  Farm  workers  will  be  paid  in  cash  wages,  not  in-kind.  The 
Government will receive higher tax revenues from the subsector. Benefits 
resulting  from  the  farm-by-farm  analysis  and  resolution  will  include 
financially  viable  farms  in  participating  raions,  with  a  flow-on  effect  of 
positive models for indebted farms to use in other raions. The conservative 
estimate of project impact on national poverty reduction is 3%, but it could 
be as high as 7–10%. 
 
The  main  risks  relating to  the  Project  are  inadequate  commitment  to  and 
engagement  in  reform-based  activities.  Local  governments  and  investors 
in  the  pilot  raions  may  create  obstacles  to  resolution,  and  Tajikstandard 
and  other  government  bodies  may  resist  changes  to  cotton  grading  and 
pricing.  These  risks  will  be  mitigated  by  information  dissemination, 
communications  for  the  establishment  of  strategic  alliances,  capacity 
building, policy work and advocacy, and engagement of and reinforcement 
by  national  government  at  the  highest  levels.  As  commercial  banks  may 
hesitate to innovate in cotton lending, the relending rate will be set so that 
it is attractive for PCBs to innovate and absorb the lending risks.

Assumptions 

 

  

 

vii 

The main assumption of the Project relates to the Government’s continued 
commitment  to  implement  essential  medium-term  measures,  particularly 
up-scaling  the  debt  resolution  process  at  a  subsector-wide  level,  and 
putting  into  place  the  medium-term  policy  and  institutional  reforms  as 
outlined  in  the  CFDRS  and  the  upcoming  road  map  for  sustainable 
development.  The  donor  community  is  making  concerted  efforts  in 
monitoring  the  implementation  of  the  CFDRS  and  the  road  map,  and 
providing additional support to the Government to implement the medium-
term  commitments.  Additionally,  Tajikistan’s  representatives  to  the  World 
Bank and ADB, who serve as members of the IC, will continue to influence 
the IC to bring about the necessary reform measures.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan,  and  (ii)  a  proposed  grant,  both  to  the  Republic  of  Tajikistan  for  the  Sustainable  Cotton 
Subsector Project.  
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE,  PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

 
2. 
Tajikistan  is  a  small,  mountainous,  landlocked  country  whose  geographic  location  and 
history  present  formidable  barriers  to  sustainable  growth.  Of  the  total  area  of  14.3  million 
hectares (ha), only 4.3 million ha is agricultural land and only 0.8 million ha is arable. Seventy 
percent of Tajikistan’s 6.4 million people live in rural areas, with land availability of 0.21 ha per 
person.  The  main  exports,  cotton  and  aluminum,  are  transported  through  Uzbekistan1 and  the 
Kyrgyz Republic. The country’s transport costs of its produce are influenced by its political and 
economic relations with these countries.  
 
Tajikistan has a narrow economic base,2 with the agriculture sector providing the major 
3. 
source  of  livelihood  for  more  than  64%  of  the  country’s  population.  Agricultural  growth  during 
the  post-civil  war  recovery  years  of  1998–2004  was  a  significant  factor  in  improving  internal 
security and ensuring political stability. In 2004, sector output generated 22% of gross domestic 
product (GDP), 20% of exports, 67% of employment, and 39% of tax revenues. Rural poverty 
incidence declined from 83% in 1999 to 64% in 2003. However, this growth is not sustainable 
because of lack of crop diversity, a narrow export base, and structural barriers that limit market 
competition.  
 
Crop  production,  which  accounts  for  74%  of  agricultural  output,  is  dominated  by  the 
4. 
cotton subsector. Cotton is grown on 50% of the country’s irrigated farmland. In 2004, the cotton 
subsector provided 60% of the value of total agriculture output, 75% of agriculture trade, 18% of 
total  export  receipts,  and  about  35%  of  tax  revenues.  Cotton  incomes  supported  75%  of  farm 
households  and  75%  of  Tajikistan’s  poor  and  extremely  poor  households.  Its  significant 
contribution  to  rural  livelihoods,  government  revenues,  and  export  incomes  makes  it  key  to 
Tajikistan’s overall development.  Appendix 2 contains a more detailed subsector analysis. 
 
A. 
 
5. 
The  cotton  subsector  is  underperforming.  At  the  farm  level,  average  yield  in  2005  was 
estimated  at  1.55  tons  per  ha  (tph),  down  from  2.80  tph  in  1991,  and  only  55%  of  the  yield 
required for reasonable profits. It takes 250–350 person-hours to produce 1 ton of seed cotton 
in  Tajikistan,  more  than  four  times  the  international  competitive  level.  Input  use  has  been 
suboptimal because of untimely delivery of vital inputs, a rise in input costs, poor input quality 
(especially  seed),  and  lack  of  access  to  appropriate  forms  of  credit.  Irrigation  facilities  have 
deteriorated and service delivery has been inefficient. Salinity and waterlogging problems have 
worsened  and  land  quality  has  declined  because  of  improper  water  and  land  use.  Finally, 
external factors contributing to the problem include declines in the world prices for fiber cotton 
and increasing prices of production inputs such as fuel, fertilizer, and minerals. 
 
6. 
Agriculture sector growth is hampered by the huge existing debt burdens of the majority 
of  cotton  farms.  Since  commercial  banks  in  Tajikistan  have  had  very  limited  resources  and 
capacity for lending to agriculture, there are virtually no formal financial sector mechanisms for 
financing  crop  production.  Accordingly,  a  number  of  local  agents  referred  in  the  country  as 
                                                 
1   About 95% of Tajikistan’s exports pass through the rail link via Uzbekistan.  
2   Aluminum, cotton, and fruit and vegetables account for 40% of gross domestic product (GDP). Cotton, aluminum, 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

and electricity generate about 86% of the country’s export revenues.    

 2 

 

“investors”  (or  futures  traders)  have  provided  virtually  all  seasonal  lending  through  production 
contract  agreements  for  cotton,  supplying  in-kind  credit  to  farmers  at  12-18%  per  annum,  and 
being  repaid  in  fiber  cotton  produced.  The  investors  have  been  important  credit  outlets, 
providing  about  75–85%  of  the  credit  needs  of  cotton  farms.  However,  their  business  and 
lending practices have created significant problems in farm debt repayment.   
 
7. 
Total outstanding cotton seasonal production debt carryover from previous years’ loans 
was estimated at $292.80 million in January 2006.3 This is equivalent to over three full seasons 
of financing.4 Debt per ha ranges from $500 to over $8,000. However, these per ha debt levels 
in  Tajikistan  do  not  reflect  a  farm’s  ability  to  pay,  the  actual  amount  borrowed,  and  the 
repayment levels. The actual amounts which creditors claim that farmers owe them are widely 
disputed.   
 
Prices  received  by  cotton  farmers  are  much  lower  than  their  counterparts  receive  in 
8. 
other cotton producing countries. The ratio of ex-gin price of fiber cotton to the cost, insurance, 
freight (CIF) price of cotton received by a Tajik farmer is 52% while Australian farmers receive 
90–92%. Lower prices and price shares are due to the distorted and imperfect arrangements in 
cotton  processing  and  marketing.  The  most  serious  impediments  are  the  inefficiencies  of 
ginneries,  weak  marketing  systems,  and  the  underpricing  and  undervaluation  of  baled  cotton. 
Although  42  privately  run  ginneries5 are  in  operation  in  the  country  in  2006,  the  majority  have 
low  outturn  averages  (22–32%). 6 Structural  limitations  include  lack  of  investment  in  ginning 
technology—half of the ginneries were built over 50 years ago—and limited access to electricity 
during the peak ginning season.7 Inefficiencies of ginneries are also due to lack of competition, 
which is a result of the debt repayment mechanisms and restricted movement of cotton between 
districts. Because of their monopsony8 position, ginners tend to extract rents from the farms. In 
addition,  the  current  cotton  classification  and  grading  standard  systems  are  inadequate  to 
determine  true  baled  cotton  quality,  forcing  down  the  price  received  by  farmers  for  their  seed 
cotton and/or fiber cotton.  
 
An  unprofitable  cotton  subsector  is  inextricably  linked  to  poverty.  While  recent  growth 
9. 
rates  have  resulted  in  the  reduction  of  poverty  incidence,  the  proportion  of  poor  rural 
households  remains  highest  in  Sughd  and  Khatlon.  About  65%  of  the  total  population  lives  in 
these two oblasts (regions). The probability of being poor is higher in these two cotton-growing 
areas than in the other regions.9 Cotton farm workers constitute the bulk of the rural labor force 
and the rural poor. More than 75% of the estimated 400,000 farm workers in the subsector are

 Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

women.10 Minors  and  employees  of  government  office  and  private-run  organizations  are  also 
employed,  especially  during  harvesting  season.  Enhancing  cotton  farm  profitability  is  thus  a 
priority agenda for alleviating rural income poverty and child labor in Tajikistan. 
 
B. 
 
10. 
Unresolved  Farm  Debt  and  Structural  Constraints.  Since  1998,  cotton  farm  debts 
have  been  accumulating.  Lenders  have  not  responded  to  the  usual  market  signals  of  non-
repayment  by slowing down cotton lending, and  there have been no efforts to consider farms’ 
capacity to repay on a sustainable basis. This has been largely due to a confluence of internal 
factors:  (i)  government  interference  in  production  decision,  (ii)  lopsided  production  contracting 
arrangements, and (iii) lack of enforcement of regulations. 
 
The  cotton  subsector  has  a  strategic  role  in  generating  fiscal  revenues,  so  the 
11. 
Government has maintained a strong hold on the key operations in the subsector’s value chain. 
Each  year,  the  Government  develops  national  and  raion  (district)  cotton  production  forecasts. 
The  rais  (local  governors)  who  are  appointed  directly  by  the  President  of  Tajikistan  are  held 
accountable  for  ensuring  that  farms  meet  the  forecasts  in  their  jurisdiction.  To  meet  the 
production targets, the rais require farmers to cultivate cotton in at least 70% of their farmland. 
The rais has significant influence over farmers because of their authority to revoke farmers’ land 
use  certificates  on  the  basis  of  the  “irrational  use”  of  agriculture  land  as  stated  in  the  Land 
Code.11 Tax revenues at the district level are tied to the amount of fiber cotton specified in that 
district, so local governments grant monopsony rights to investors and gins to keep all seed and 
fiber cotton sales and ginning in the local raion. 
 
An uncompetitive market environment in input financing encourages the use of lopsided 
12. 
production  contract  agreements  that  favor  the  investor  to  the  detriment  of  the  farmer.  The 
production  loan  contract  does  not  stipulate  the  price  of  raw  cotton  and  inputs,  and  does  not 
penalize the investor for late input delivery or a less-than-technically-optimal amount or quality 
of inputs. The problem is further aggravated by the lack of transparency or accountability of farm 
association  managers  and/or  accountants  to  farm  owners  and  members  for  financial 
arrangements. 
 
The  debt  problems  of  the  cotton  subsector  are  exacerbated  by  lack  of  enforcement  of 
13. 
regulations  of  the  National  Bank  of  Tajikistan  (NBT)  for  KreditInvest  on  its  cotton  lending 
operations  through  (i)  inadequate  legal  mechanisms  and  court  systems  to  address  debt 
disputes, (ii) inadequate systems of accounting for bad debt in investor businesses, and (iii) the 
assumption that the Government would deal with the debt overhang as it had done in previous 
periods.12   
 
14. 
The net effect of accumulating cotton farm debt on farmers has been devastating. The 
usual incentives to improve productivity and maximize net returns do not work because of the 
complex  web  of  rent-extractive  market  arrangements.  Many  farmers  produce  cotton  only 
because they are instructed to do so by local governments which have control over the farmers’

have been monitored properly to ensure its transparent channeling in the budget.  

3 

 

 land  use  rights,  and  because  cotton  is  the  only  crop  for  which  farmers  can  borrow  funds  to 
produce.  Thus,  cotton  yields  in  recent  years  have  not  only  been  low  but  have  shown  a 
fluctuating trend.  
 
15. 
Lack  of  Alternative  Rural  Financing  Mechanisms.  Access  to  seasonal  production 
credit for cotton is a critical input for the sustained growth of the cotton subsector. The banking 
sector  in  Tajikistan  is  extremely  small,  with  only  $160  million  in  total  outstanding  assets  as  of 
March 2006 and a deposit-to-GDP ratio of 4%. With a delinquency rate of 36% on its 13.4% of 
total portfolio in agriculture, formal financial institutions are understandably cautious in lending to 
agriculture. Lending to the agricultural sector has been effectively frozen because of heavy farm 
debt  levels  and  related  liquidity  and  institutional  capacity  restrictions.  It  will  be  impossible  to 
generate  agricultural  financing  from  international  financial  organizations  and  the  private  sector 
unless  cotton  farm  debt  is  resolved  in  a  transparent  and  voluntary  manner  between  creditors 
and  farmers.  Banks  and  other  financial  institutions  expect  to  develop  capability  to  lend  to 
agriculture  over  the  next  2–3  years,  but  currently  there  are  neither  funds  nor  institutional 
capacity in the financial market to provide full sector financing.      
 
Farm  Restructuring  in  Tandem  with  Farm  Debt  Reallocation.  The  breakup  of 
16. 
collective state farms into private farms, with active farmers holding land use right certificates, is 
an important component of the agricultural reform program. The farm restructuring process has 
resulted in an increase of cotton farms, from 658 farms at year-end 2002 to over 22,000 farms 
in early 2006. While the initial phase of farm restructuring is practically complete, no systematic 
attention  has  been  given  to  the  reassignment  or  assumption  of  public  or  private  farm  debt 
obligations. Under a Presidential Decree, private debt was reassigned on a per-irrigated hectare 
basis  after  consideration  of  machinery  and  other  non-land  asset  distribution.  As  of  1  October 
2005,  approximately  61%  of  restructured  farms  had  signed  debt  reallocation  agreements,  and 
the  process  is  ongoing.  However,  the  debt  reallocation  process  was  undertaken  without 
reviewing  the  accuracy  of  debt,  without  reference  to  the  new  farm’s  capacity  to  repay  the 
assigned  debt,  and  with  inadequate  attention  to  distribution  of  other  farm  assets.  Debt-related 
data  on  larger  farms  have  not  been  reflected  in  the  newly  subdivided  farms,  making 
reconstructions of debt history difficult. This will complicate investor capacity to engage with and 
manage farm debtors, and will also significantly increase the size and complexity of farm debt 
resolution.    
 
17. 
Cotton  Grading  Classification  System  and  Price  Setting.  Current  Tajikstandard 
classification  systems  and  practices  in  cotton  grading  do  not  adequately  reflect  the  quality  of 
cotton  and  the  price  differential  that  can  be  obtained  in  the  marketplace.  The  pricing  formula 
further  exerts  a  downward  push  on  the  price  of  baled  cotton.  The  Government,  through 
Tajikistan’s Universal Goods Exchange (TUGE), sets the export price formula by adjusting the 
CIF to the free on board (FOB) price of fiber cotton with higher nonmarket cost deductions and 
based  on a lower  cotton  grade.  This  results  in  revenue  losses  to  exporters  and  farmers.  Poor 
export  pricing  mechanisms,  inadequate  grading  systems,  and  poor  market  infrastructure  cost 
the country a minimum of $14 million a year in lost income. A new approach to classification and 
issuance  of  grade  certificates  as  well  as  improvements  in  marketing  infrastructure,  pricing 
systems, and mechanisms are needed to (i) increase the confidence of external buyers in the 
quality of fiber cotton sold, and (ii) improve the price received for Tajik fiber cotton.   
 
18. 
Response from Government. In March 2005, the President of Tajikistan approved the 
Cotton  Farm  Debt  Resolution  Strategy  (CFDRS,  Supplementary  Appendix  A).  The  strategy 
focuses first on resolving the immediate and urgent problem of a huge debt overhang through 
the  facilitation  of  debt workouts  between  private  lenders  and  private  borrowers.  The  proposed 
policy  reforms  include  (i)  removal  of  the  cotton  targets  or  implicit  quotas;  (ii)  securing  of  land 
tenure;  (iii)  establishing  international  grading  standards;  (iv)  giving  farmers  the  freedom  to

lending system. The strategy calls for the establishment of the Independent Commission (IC) to

The President of Tajikistan has taken the lead in overseeing the implementation of the

(ADB) and World Bank to discuss the progress on the resolution of farm debt (Supplementary 
Appendix A). The President has also endorsed the development of a cotton subsector road map 
that  will  allow  the  Government  and  all  concerned  stakeholders  to  keep  track  of  concrete 
progress  in  resolving  the  farm  debts  and  addressing  other  related  sector  reform  issues,  as 
identified in the CFDRS and the action plan, in a realistic time frame. The road map is currently 
being developed by the Government and the international community (Supplementary Appendix 
B).

from 
Commonwealth  of  Independent  States  (CIS)  countries  on  post-independence  farm  debt 
resolution,  (ii)  international  cotton  organizations  for  marketing  support  structures  and  pricing 
mechanisms,  and  (iii)  ADB’s  initial  work  on  this  issue  in  2003  and  thereafter.  In  successful 
cases  in  Moldova  and  Ukraine,  the  debt  restructuring  process  included  the  use  of  a 
multidisciplinary  team  to  complete  in-depth  analyses  of  the  farms’  financial  and  productive 
capacity  to  determine  their  capacity  to  pay  the  debt.  A  policy  team  supplemented  field  team 
operations to ensure ongoing agriculture reforms as required. Farm debt laws were developed 
using  lessons  from  the  farm-by-farm  analysis.  Participatory  dissemination  of  information  to 
major stakeholders about the debt process was also an important feature of that debt resolution 
process  (see  Supplementary  Appendix  C  for  details  and  other  country  experiences). 
Additionally, the experiences of countries that are members of international cotton associations 
highlight the benefits of (i) applying internationally recognized cotton classification standards, (ii) 
the use of transparent and independent classification firms, (iii) appropriate marketing facilities 
such as bonded warehousing, and (iv) the application of a market-based export pricing system 
and  pricing  mechanisms.13 The  cotton  subsector  cases  of  Kyrgyz  Republic,  People’s  Republic 
of  China,  and  Kazakhstan  highlight  the  high-income  shares  that  farmers  can  receive  from 
efficient  market-based  operations  at  the  farm,  ginnery,  and  input  provision  levels.  ADB  and 
World  Bank  projects  on  pilot-testing  policy  reforms  of  fixed  and  lower  quotas  for  cotton  and 
wheat  in  a  few  districts  in  Uzbekistan 14show  positive  improvements  in  yield  and  economic 
returns  of  farmers,  and  changing  mindsets  among  hukumats  (district  governments)  regarding 
the necessity of production quotas.

Response of ADB. The country strategy and program15 emphasizes rural development. 
22. 
The  attainment  of  broad-based  growth  of  the  cotton  subsector  is  key  to  achieving  rural 
development  and  poverty  reduction.  ADB’s  comprehensive  work  on  farm  debt  under  the 
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Farm  Debt  Resolution  and  Policy  Reforms 16  highlighted  the 
complex issue of the cotton debt overhang, its debilitating impact on the rural economy, and the 
urgent  need  for  a  holistic  approach  to  cotton  subsector  development.  This  study  and  other 
follow-on  analysis  resulted  in  recommendations  for  a  combination  of  policy,  investment,  and 
institutional reforms. When implemented together, these reforms—now known as the IC action 
plan of the CFDRS—will ensure sustainable improvements in the overall cotton subsector. The 
TA  for  Farm  Analysis  and  Awareness-Raising  for  Debt  Resolution17 will  undertake  initial  tasks 
under the action plan with DfID and World Bank projects.   
 
There is an urgent need to support the recovery of the cotton subsector. Key financing 
23. 
gaps  in  the  immediate  term  are  accumulating  farm  debt,  policy  constraints  to  producer’s 
incentives, new forms of crop financing, and structural bottlenecks that create distortions in the 
processing  and  marketing  sides  of  the  value  chain.  Addressing  these  gaps  will  enable  cotton 
farms to reap the potential benefits of a vertically integrated value chain and significantly reduce 
rural poverty. The Project will address these areas.

A. 
 
24. 
The Project’s expected impact is the development of an economically sustainable cotton 
subsector in Tajikistan’s two major cotton-producing regions, Khatlon and Sughd. Its outcome is 
for the debt-restructured cotton farms in Vose and Yovon raions of Khatlon and Mastchoh and 
Zafarabad  raions  in  Sughd  to  sustainably  improve  their  financial  viability  based  on  market 
principles.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in  Appendix  1.  Appendix  4  discusses  the 
Project’s chronology of processing schedule. 
 
B. 
 
The Project will provide three key outputs to achieve the desired outcome. The two key 
25. 
outputs in the four selected cotton-producing raions are that (i) the strategies, policy measures, 
and mechanisms to effectively address and resolve indebtedness of cotton farms are in place; 
and (ii) participating commercial banks (PCBs) provide suitable financing products and services 
to  the  debt-restructured  cotton  farms.  At  the  supply  chain’s  marketing  level,  the  Project’s  third 
output is putting into effect grading and marketing regulations, a joint venture (JV) established 
by  the  Government  with  an  internationally  recognized  cotton  classification  organization,  and 
bonded warehousing of cotton following international standards. To support the delivery of the 
outputs, an effective Common Center for Project Management (CCfPM) will be established.

26. 
are (i) farm-by-farm analysis; (ii) debt resolution processes, including facilitated farmer-creditor 
negotiations;  (iii)  policy  measures  for  debt  resolution;  and  (iv)  support  for  public  information 
processes.  Supplementary  Appendix  C  contains  a  more  detailed  discussion  of  the  farm  debt 
resolution  process.  Based  on  criteria  agreed  between  the  Government  and  ADB,  the  IC  has 
selected Vose and Yovon in Khatlon region, and Mastchoh and Zafarabad in Sughd regions as 
the  raions  where  the  farm  debt  resolution  process  will  be  undertaken.  Khamadon  and  Jami 
raions in Khatlon are set aside as reserve areas if the Project is able to expand to these raions 
(Supplementary  Appendix  E  presents  the  criteria  for  the  selection  of  the  raions).  The  IC  will 
ensure  that  the  rais  in  the  selected  raions  will  provide  full  support  to  the  teams  from 
commencement of any work in the raions. 
 
27. 
A  multidisciplinary  team  will  be  mobilized  for  each  raion  to  handle  the  farm-by-farm 
analysis  and  debt  resolution  process  in  the  four  designated  raions.  The  teams  will  work  on 
participating farms with investors and farmers to create an accurate picture of the debt level and 
farm  operations.  Based  on  the  findings,  a  trained  negotiating  team  will  work  with  the  raion-
based mobile teams to assist farm management and farm owners in negotiating with creditors a 
mutually agreed restructuring and settlement of the farm’s cotton debt which takes into account 
the validated debt levels and the farm’s capacity to repay. The parties will conclude with a legal 
and binding agreement that provides the details of the debt restructuring. In cases where a legal 
agreement is not reached, the parties will be advised to proceed to third party arbitration, go to 
court, or agree to let the farm voluntarily file for insolvency. The mobile teams will also work with 
farm  management  and  workers  to  prepare  a  realistic  business  plan  that  includes  farm 
operations and management, a marketing plan, and financial arrangements.  
 
A support team will be established in Dushanbe to provide guidance on complex issues 
28. 
during  farm  reviews  and  negotiations.  It  will  also  provide  the  IC  with  policy  support  through 
policy studies18 and policy recommendations on debt-related and poverty and social issues. To 
upscale  the  farm  debt  assessment  and  resolution  processes,  a  farm  debt  resolution  manual, 
including  protocols  and  procedures  that  can  be  applied  sector-wide,  will  be  developed  for 
consideration  by  the  IC.  A  computer-based  financial  farm  operations  model  that  can  cover  a 
wide  range  of  farm  debt  situations  and  farm  types  will  complement  the  manual.  The 
computerized program can be used in negotiating with investors to secure broad agreements on 
debt resolution for a group of farms in a raion, thus speeding the process of debt resolution. 
 
29. 
A public outreach, communication, and education team will be established. It will assist 
the teams and the IC to build strategic alliances in support of the reform measures, and ensure 
that all stakeholders have sufficient information about the processes of market development and 
farm debt resolution to make responsible choices and act appropriately. Key activities include: 
(i)  dialogues  and  consultation  meetings  by  the  President  of  Tajikistan,  IC,  and  the  donor 
community  with  major  stakeholders  who  may  resist  the  reforms;  (ii)  dissemination  of  early 
successes  in  farm  debt  resolution,  such  as  stories  of  investors,  gin  owners,  and  rais  who 
initiated innovative and responsible schemes; and (iii) an awareness program to ensure that all 
cotton  farmers  have  access  to  relevant  information  about  the  new  classification  and  market 
regulations and/or pricing arrangements.

Common  Center  for  Project  Management.  To ensure the delivery of project outputs,

C. 
 
The grant component of the Project includes (i) financing for the farm debt resolution in 
35. 
designated raions; (ii) policy development; (iii) information, communication, and public outreach; 
(iv)  capacity  building  in  and  consulting  services  for  market  development,  and  the  agriculture

D. 
 
36.  Maximizing  Farmers’  Returns  from  the  Value  Chain.  A three-pronged approach will 
be employed in the Project to improve farmers’ returns and turn around their unprofitable farms. 
The  debt  issue  will  be  addressed  at  the  farm  level  by  providing  farmers  with 
viable  business  plans  in  the  selected  raions  and  access  to  an  alternative  credit 
source.  The  work  in  innovative  agricultural  financing  will  stimulate  interest  and 
capacity in the private financial sector for farmer engagement, and create further 
options for farmers to directly buy from private input suppliers. 
Policy  reforms  will  address  the  reason  for  the  farmer’s  disincentive  to  produce, 
and  the  market  distortions  that  make  the  supply  chain  ineffective.  Numerous 
options for farmers to increase income will be created by the requirement that the 
selected  raions  implement  a  broader  range  of  reforms,  including  giving  farmers 
the  fundamental  right  to  choose  production  options,  security  of  land  rights  from 
arbitrary  seizure,  and  release  from  requirements  to  deliver  all  cotton  to  specific 
ginneries.

At  the  subsector  level,  the  investments  at  the  downstream  level  of  the  supply 
chain  will  enhance  the  income  returns  of  all  farmers  from  better  quality  of  seed 
cotton and fiber cotton. With support from the Project, Tajikistan will shift to the 
most widely accepted cotton grading standards system. A JV will be established 
with controlling majority interest held by an internationally accepted independent 
cotton  grading  controller  company.  This,  along  with  export  pricing  reform  and 
private  investments  in  bonded  warehouses,  will  bring  about  higher  prices 
generally for Tajik fiber cotton, clarity among farmers regarding their options for 
increasing  cotton  quality  and  prices,  a  better  and  fairer  balance  in  the  share  of 
profits between farmers and traders, and increased private sector investments in 
the cotton subsector.  

 

The  demonstration  effects  of  this  three-pronged  approach  to  expanding  farmers’  incomes  will 
reach  far  beyond  the  indebted  farms  in  the  designated  raions  to  other  farms  and  adjoining 
districts. Replication is expected to be rapid for changes that demonstrate the most far-reaching 
improvements.   
 
Responsiveness  to  Poverty,  Gender,  and  Child  Labor  Issues.  The  Project 
37. 
recognizes that (i) the majority of the poor depend on earnings from the cotton subsector; (ii) an 
estimated  75%  of  cotton  farm  workers  are  women;  and  (iii)  child  labor  is  employed  regularly 
during  harvest  season.  To  address  these  social  issues,  consultation  processes  for  farm  debt 
resolution in the designated  raions will be undertaken before the review process and continue 
throughout  the  debt  workout.  Social  participation  specialists  in  the  raion-based  teams  will 
ensure  that  shareholders  and  workers  have  a  clear  understanding  of  the  process  and  their 
rights  and  responsibilities.  Debt  resolutions  (especially  in  development  of  the  business  plans) 
will take into account their implications on the poor and vulnerable groups. A related grant from 
the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) is planned to enable special activities for poorer 
households,  particularly  those  led  by  women,  to  diversify  their  income  sources  and  access 
credit through microfinance (footnote 19). The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is 
in Appendix 6.

financing  is  to  assist  the  Government  in  resolving  cotton  farm  debt  through  (i)  farm-by-farm 
analysis  and  debt  resolutions  in  the  designated  raions;  (ii)  capacity  building  and  stakeholders’ 
awareness  training  activities  on  the  UCGS  and  debt  workout;  (iii)  policy  measures  on  and 
advocacy  for  sustainable  debt  resolution  and  better  marketing  of  cotton;  (iv)  transparent 
selection  of  PCBs  for  the  agriculture  financing  innovation  schemes;  and  (v)  support  for  the 
CCfPM.   
 
41. 
The proposed loan will finance 36.0% of the total project cost and will be applied to meet 
the  costs  of  the  agriculture  financing  innovations,  financing  of  the  Government's  equity 
contribution  to  the  JV  cotton  classification  company,  upgrade  of  three  laboratory  facilities  and 
essential equipment for the JV, and the upgrade of two warehouses.  
 
42. 
The Government will provide $1.75 million, or 11.4% of the total project cost, while the 
private sector will provide an amount of $1.54 million or 10.1%. The Government will provide the 
costs  of  the  project  management  staff  seconded  to  the  CCfPM,  and  in  raions;  facilities  for 
project operations in the raions and in Dushanbe; court support in cases of debt resolution; and 
will  waive  duties  and  taxes  on  imported  vehicles  and  equipment,  in  accordance  with  ADB 
requirements  and  national  legislation.  The  private  sector’s  contribution  will  primarily  be  in  the 
form of equity contribution of the selected internationally accepted independent cotton controller 
to  the  JV,  investment  in  international  standard  warehouse  services,  and  farmer  and  investor 
time and work to resolve debt issues. 
 
G. 
 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Project Management 

 
The  Executive  Office  of  the  President  (EOP)  will  be  the  EA for  the  Project.  The  IC will 
43. 
serve  as  the  project  steering  committee  to  provide  policy  guidance  and  reform  support  during 
the farm debt resolution process, the agriculture finance innovations, and the marketing policies, 
consistent with the action plan of the CFDRS and the road map. MOA will be the Implementing 
Agency (IA) for the JV and bonded warehouse activities, and the CCfPM will serve as the IA for 
the  farm  debt  resolution  in  designated  raions  and  the  agriculture  financing  innovation.  The 
specific  functions  of  these  agencies  and  the  management  organizational  chart  are  in 
Supplementary Appendix G. 

 

 12 

44. 
The  Government  will  establish  the  CCfPM  before  31  December  2006  to  serve  as  the 
Project’s  communication  link  with  the  IC  on  policy  matters  on  farm  debt  resolution,  marketing 
issues, and other institutional concerns. The Center will be the responsibility of the EOP25 and 
will be functionally accountable to the IC and its chairperson. A short list of candidates for the 
Center  director  will  be  competitively  determined.  From  this  list,  the  Government  will  select  the 
most  suitable  to  be  the  Center  director,  to  be  endorsed  by  ADB.  The  Project  will  fund  the 
salaries of staff and some operational costs of the Center.  
 
45. 
The financial management assessment (Supplementary Appendix H) of potential EAs for 
the  Project  (EOP,  NBT,  and  MOA)  concluded  that  the  EAs  examined  do  not  have  direct 
experience  in  project  implementation.  In  addition,  they  have  accounting  weaknesses  and  are 
not  technically  equipped  to  administer  project  funds.  Therefore,  a  project  implementation  unit 
(PIU)  will  be  established  for  the  Project  and  will  be  under  the  CCfPM.  In  order  to  encourage 
donor harmonization, sustainability, and cost saving, the Project’s PIU will be established jointly 
with the World Bank’s anticipated Cotton Sector Recovery and Poverty Reduction Project.  
 

2. 

Agricultural Financing Innovation Bank Selection and Monitoring 

 
46. 
Four PCBs have undergone detailed financial and management reviews under the ADB 
Private  Sector  Operations  Department  Trade  Facility  and  under  the  European  Bank  for 
Reconstruction  and  Development’s  (EBRD’s)  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  lending 
program.  These  PCBs  continue  to  qualify  for  access  to  either  of  these  two  facilities  and  meet 
NBT  supervision  requirements,  and  they  may  apply  for  funding  under  the  agriculture  finance 
innovation  component  of  the  Project.  Interested  PCBs  may  submit  tender  proposals  for  a 
subloan to be used to lend to debt-restructured farms in the designated raions. Tendering will be 
in a format suitable to the IC and ADB.  
 
47. 
The proposals from the PCBs will be submitted to the CCfPM and banking consultant for 
evaluation and recommendation, with final approval from the IC and ADB. Up to three proposals 
are expected to be selected based on (i) feasibility and product creativity, potential client impact, 
planned spread, and potential for sustainable product expansion beyond the project area; and 
(ii)  percentage  of  PCB's  own  contribution  to  the  expansion  plan.  The  subloan  size  to  each 
selected  bank  is  limited  to  20%  of  equity,  substantiated  by  the  bank’s  annual  audited 
statements. Once selected, the PCBs will sign SLAs with the Government in a form acceptable 
to ADB. The PCBs will be regularly monitored by the CCfPM for their compliance of the criteria.

Consulting Services 

 
50. 
The  Project  will  provide  62  allocated  person-months  of  international  consultants  and 
1,207 allocated person-months of national consultants for the following areas: (i) conduct of the

resolution  activities  and  processes  as  well  as  cotton  grading  and  marketing  improvements; 
(vii) policy  formulation  for  IC  consideration  on  issues  related  to  the  CFDRS;  and  (viii)  project 
management  services  and  an  effective  communication  link  with  the  IC.  Unallocated  person-
months  equivalent  to  24  person-months  of  national  consultants  and  6  person-months  of

51. 
The consulting services for farm debt resolution will be provided by an international firm, 
in association with national consultants or a national consulting firm. These will be recruited in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants, using full technical proposals and 
quality-based selection (QBS). The QBS method will be used to ensure the selection of a good 
mix of highly qualified consultants with a track record on farm debt mediations and development 
of  farm  recovery  plans.  It  is  important  that  the  consultants  be  selected  on  the  basis  of  their 
technical merit and extensive work experience in resolving farm debt because the Government 
puts high priority on the expedient resolution of this problem through subsector-wide replication 
of  the  protocols  and  procedures  to  be  developed  under  the  Project.  Moreover,  farm  debt 
resolution  has  a  significant  downstream  impact  not  just  at  the  subsector  level  but  also  at  the 
agriculture sector in general. The international firm to be selected for implementation of the farm 
debt  resolution  component  will  be  engaged  for  three  years  subject  to  an  annual  performance 
review before each year commences. An assessment of the international firm’s performance will 
be  done  jointly  by  the  EA  and  ADB  in  a  timely  manner  to  enable  extension  of  services  to  the 
following year.  
 
52. 
Quality-  and  cost-based  selection  (QCBS)  will  be  used  for  cotton  market  development, 
and awareness training for UCGS and bonded warehouses. Modified (simplified) QCBS will be 
used  for  the  engagement  of  NGOs  to  conduct  awareness  training  and  development  of  PPMS 
and the gender action plan. Individual selection will be used for the identification of director for 
the CCfPM, while least-cost selection will be applied for the auditing firm for the external audit 
service. Biodata technical proposals will be used for these consulting selection methods.

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

 

62. 
A political economy framework, combined with a value chain and benefit-cost analysis, 
was  used  in  (i)  assessing  the  economic  and  social  rationale  for  the  set  of  measures;  and 
(ii) evaluating the net benefits and impact of the Project. Under a distorted market situation, as 
in the case of Tajikistan’s cotton subsector’s value chain, the economic returns accruing to the 
participants  in  the  value  chain  are  not  maximized.  Leakages  through  rent-extractive  means 
arise,  and  the  economic  returns  are  unequally  distributed  among  the  players.  These  result  in 
economic losses to the subsector and the national economy in general. Appendix 11 discusses 
the  financial  and  economic  analysis  in  detail,  while  the  comprehensive  assessment  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix J. 
 

 

 16 

Project Benefits  

A. 
 
63. 
Benefits resulting from farm-by-farm analysis and debt resolution will include financially 
viable  farms  in  the  participating  raions.  These  farms  will  have  substantially  reduced  their  debt 
and  will  have  a  net  income  that  enables  payment  for  all  short-term  operating  requirements  as 
well  as  repayment  of  restructured  debt.  Benefits  from  the  agricultural  financing  innovation  in 
designated  raions  include  (i)  more  rapid  farm  implementation  of  post-restructuring  business 
options,  (ii)  restoration  of  creditor  confidence  in  those  farms,  and  (iii)  facilitation  of  more 
innovative and client-responsive commercial bank services to the general farming community.   
 
64. 
Removing market distortions, and improving the efficiency of processing seed cotton and 
marketing fiber cotton, have been estimated to increase the farm gate price for seed cotton by 
$354  per  ton  (t).  This  amounts  to  a  49.0%  increase  in  farm  gate  returns.  On  the  basis  of 
448,000  t  of  seed  cotton  produced  in  2005,  total  farm  income  increases  by  $52 million  per 
annum.27 In the four designated raions, the improved economic returns for seed cotton together 
with changes to the cropping pattern and the forecast increase in cotton yield from 1.8 t/ha to 
2.4 t/ha gives an economic internal rate of return of 28.7%. 
 
65. 
Under  a  “without  project”  scenario,  the  farmers'  share  of  total  margin  in  the  marketing 
and distribution system is relatively small, with only 52.0% of the total value of fiber cotton and 
65.0%  of  the  value  derived  from  the  sale  of  cotton  by-products.  With  the  Project,  this  total 
margin is estimated to improve to 67.0% of the value from fiber cotton and 75.0% from the value 
of cotton by-products accruing to farmers.  
 
66. 
Increased government revenues through higher cotton tax collection as well as reduction 
in resource wastage due to market distortions will mean more funds available for the provision 
of public goods. Estimates of additional government revenues are about $2.3 million per annum. 
  
There are social benefits to improved returns for poor farmers (Appendix 6).  In a World 
67. 
Bank  study,  it  was  estimated  that  a  10.0%  increase  in  cotton  yield  would  result  in  a  1.5% 
decrease  in  poverty  incidence.  These  computations  were  conducted  for  the  “without  project” 
scenario. The conservative estimate on poverty reduction is 3.0%, but it may go as high as 7.0–
10.0%  at  the  end  of  the  Project.  As  women  farmers  comprise  a  large  shareholding  in  cotton 
farms,  the  Project  will  benefit  women.  Combined  with  a  public  outreach  that  disseminates  the 
success stories, the results will have multiplier effects.  
 
68.  With changes in crop financing, farm workers’ wages will be paid in cash and not in kind 
(cotton stems and limited cottonseed oil). This will be a boost to the impoverished farm workers, 
mostly women and children.  
 
69. 
The  use  of  child  labor  during  cotton  harvesting  will  diminish  in  the  medium  term  with 
improved  incomes.  In  the  short  term,  business  plans  of  restructured  indebted  farms  will 
incorporate  measures  that  will  discourage  the  employment  of  child  labor.  Mitigation  measures 
will also be put in place in situations where farms declare bankruptcy.    
 
Reduction of market distortions, combined with a public outreach program, will enhance 
70. 
the bargaining leverage of poor farmers and vulnerable groups in the subsector. The Project will 
showcase the economic and social benefits of reduced market distortions and more transparent 
and accountable governance among players in the subsector.  
 

                                                 
27 This ignores any allowance for changes in the cropping pattern or for increased yields, which would eventually be 

expected in a less regulated environment and with the incentive of improved farm gate prices.   

 

 17 

Project Sustainability 

71. 
There  are  no  perceived  environmental  costs  arising  from  the  Project  but  mitigation 
measures  are  nevertheless  proposed  in  the  business  plans  for  the  debt-restructured  farms  to 
ensure  that  the  use  of  harmful  pesticides  and  chemicals  will  not  intensify  (Appendix  12  and 
Supplementary Appendix K). 
 
B. 
 
72. 
In conjunction with the financial management assessment of the proposed EA, a review 
was conducted to determine the financial viability of those aspects of the Project with ongoing 
recurrent cost implications. The main project measures to which this applies is the upgrade of 
three  laboratories  for  the  JV,  adoption  of  the  UCGS,  and  the  use  of  two  bonded  warehouses. 
Revenues  generated  from  fees  charged  for  the  service  of  ensuring  accurate  cotton 
classifications and the lease option for the warehouses will be more than adequate to finance 
the operation and maintenance of the laboratory and the bonded warehouses on a sustainable 
basis. 
 
73. 
To ensure sustainable resolution of farm debt and development of the cotton subsector, 
the Government has formulated a comprehensive CFDRS that defines the short- and medium-
term policy and institutional reforms. An action plan for the strategy has been developed by the 
Government  in  close  consultation  with  the  donor  community.  A  road  map  is  also  being 
developed, jointly by the Government and the international community, which will prioritize and 
sequence  the  policy  measures  for  the  cotton  subsector’s  turnaround.  The  action  plan  and  the 
road map are being monitored and are periodically discussed by the donor community with the 
IC to ensure effective attainment of the expected outcomes. Continued support from the donor 
community  for  the  implementation  of  the  medium-term  measures  under  the  CFDRS  and  the 
road  map  will  be  maintained  through  the  support  of  ADB  and  World  Bank  resident  missions, 
which have representations in the IC.   
  
C. 
 
74. 
The  main  risks  relating  to  the  Project  are  from  stakeholders  who  have  political  and 
economic  power  and  who  may  incur  losses  in  the  short  term  from  the  reform  and  investment 
measures.  These  risks  will  be  mitigated  by  a  combination  of  direct  ongoing  quarterly 
consultations with the President of Tajikistan and a proactive communication program to ease 
resistance  and  build  strategic  alliances,  information  dissemination,  education,  and  capacity 
building.  This  will  include  dissemination  of  early  success  stories  in  the  farm  debt  resolution 
exercise. The IC will play a critical role in ensuring the full cooperation of investors and rais. The 
President  has  spearheaded  reforms  by  instructing  key  ministries  to  help  ensure  investor 
participation in the debt audit exercise. Continued support and involvement of the President in 
debt resolution will be maintained during project implementation.  
 
The significant risk relating to the attainment of the outcome is that the rais continue to 
75. 
implement  the  one-ginnery  and  one-investor  per  district  policy  and  retain  the  authority  to 
confiscate land use rights. Government assurances have been provided at the highest level to 
ensure  that  local  governments  cooperate  with  the  debt  resolution  process  in  the  designated 
raions.  Additionally,  policy  activities  include  assessment  of  the  issue  of  tax  options  that  can 
enhance the rais’ developmental roles in local governance.28  
 
76. 
The major assumption of the Project is that the Government, through its IC, will upscale 
at  a  subsector-wide  level  the  debt  resolution  protocols  and  procedures  developed  in  the  four

a 

 

Yield performance and repayment capacity will be the basic indicators for demonstrating the financial viability of the farm. 
During the debt assessment process and the development of business plans for debt-restructured reforms, relevant farm 
financial and economic indicators will be generated to provide a more comprehensive picture of financial viability. These 
could include the farm’s (i) repayment capacity [e.g., term debt and capital lease coverage ratio, capital replacement and 
term  debt  repayment  margin];  (ii)  solvency  [debt/asset  ratio,  debt/equity  ratio];  (iii)  liquidity  [current  ratio  and  acid  test 
ratio];  (iv)  financial  efficiency  [net  farm  income  from  operations  ratio  and  asset  turnover  ratio];  and  (v)  profitability 
[operating profit margin ratio and rate of return on farm equity].

COTTON IN TAJIKISTAN: A SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 

Agriculture Sector Context 

 
1. 
In  the  last  five  years,  the  cotton  industry’s  yields  and  profitability  have  continued  to 
decline.  Market  distortions,  government  interventions  in  the  strategic  aspects  of  the  cotton’s 
supply  chain,  huge  farm  debt,  and  weaknesses  in  production  have  severely  damaged  the 
profitability of the cotton subsector. 
 
A. 
 
2. 
In 2004, the agriculture sector generated 22% of gross domestic product (GDP), 20% of 
exports, 67% of employment, and 39% of tax revenues. The sector has accounted for one third 
of Tajikistan’s economic growth since 1998, with crop production contributing about 80% of the 
sector’s growth from 1999 to 2004.1 The main crops are wheat (38% of the total crop output); 
cotton (30%); fodder crops (12%); potatoes, vegetables, fruits, and industrial crops (12%); and 
other cereals (8%).  
 
Much  of  the  crop  expansion  in  the  post-civil  war  period  (post-1997)  were  the  result  of 
3. 
changes in land use—specifically significant decreases in the area devoted to fodder crops and 
increases in land cultivating wheat and other food crops. Areas allocated for cotton production 
declined initially but have since recovered almost to the pre-independence level. Arable land in 
the country is extremely scarce (roughly 0.21 hectare [ha] per capita of the rural population) and 
irrigated  land  is  very  limited  (just  60%  of  arable  land).  While  expanded  food  production  has 
helped  reduce  food  poverty,  future  agriculture  growth  may  be  hampered    because  of  the  low 
value  share  of  food  crops,  and  because  of  environmental  concerns,  since  low-income  rural 
households (which have least access to land) would increasingly utilize marginal lands. Most of 
the  limited  irrigated  land  is  reserved  for  cotton  and  wheat  production,  where  there  are  less 
restorative crop rotations. Coupled with poor drainage and inefficient irrigation facilities, this has 
led to degradation of the soil quality.  
 
4. 
All  land  is  owned  by  the  state,  but  lifelong,  inheritable  land  use  certificates  for  dekhan 
(peasant) farms are increasingly issued. These certificates cannot be transferred or mortgaged. 
Historically,  farming  was  done  by  large  state  farms  called  sofkhozes  or  kholkhozes.  In  2001, 
there  were  687  such  farms.  Under  an  accelerated  privatization  program,  most  have  been 
broken  up  into  smaller  units.  At  the  end  of  2005,  about  27,000  dehkan  farms  were  registered 
and  provided  with  land  use  rights  certificates.2 These  farms  cover  more  than  half  of  the  total 
irrigated land and are planted mainly with cotton and wheat. In 2003, dekhan farms contributed 
20% of agriculture output and 37% of the sector’s growth. The other farm type is the household 
plot (0.1–0.3 ha) which are provided to all households for food production purposes. Although 
the aggregate area of household plots was only 17.2% of total arable hectares and only 13.9% 
of  irrigated  land  in  2003,  their  contribution  to  gross  agricultural  output  was  53.6%  of  the  total, 
and  50.8%  of  the  sector’s  growth.  The  major  difference  between  these  two  farm  types  is  the 
extent  of  freedom  to  make  farm  decisions.  Unlike  dekhan  farmers,  who  are  bound  by  local 
governments to cultivate cotton in 70% of their land and meet the allotted production target for 
seed  cotton  (or  they  lose  their  land  use  rights),  household  plot  producers  are  free  from  state 
interference.  
 
                                                 
1  World Bank. 2006. Priorities for Sustainable Growth: A Strategy for Agriculture Sector Development in Tajikistan. 

Washington, DC: World Bank.  

2  Dekhan farms are privately run smaller-sized farms averaging  170 ha per farm, created from state and collective 
farms. These  farms  are  organized  either  as  a  collective,  or  are  individual  or  family-based.  The  new  farm  owners 
have inheritable land use rights.    

 

 26 

Appendix 2 

The trade base of agriculture is narrow: cotton provides 75–90% of export values, and 
5. 
fresh  and  processed  fruits  and  vegetables  provide  the  bulk  of  the  remainder.  Export  receipts 
from  cotton  are  vulnerable  to  world  price  volatility,  while  export  revenues  from  fruits  and 
vegetables are vulnerable to the Russian market, which absorbs 95% of this trade. Both export 
crops are susceptible to the vagaries of regional politics, especially since the rail links through 
Uzbekistan  carry  95%  of  exports.  Tajikistan  imports  virtually  all  its  fertilizer,  agricultural 
chemicals,  and  fuel  from  neighboring  countries,  making  inputs  relatively  cheaper  than  direct 
purchase from producer countries further away, although there are the attendant risks of poorer 
quality and unreliable deliveries.   
 
6. 
The sector’s high growth rate was a major factor in the decline in rural poverty incidence 
(at  a  poverty  line  of  $2.15/day  purchasing  power  parity)  from  82%  in  1999  to  65%  in  2004. 
However,  sustained  poverty  reduction  will  require  the  sector  to  grow  by  at  least  at  6–7%  per 
annum.  This  would  mean  an  investment  of  $100  million-$130  million  per  year  in  irrigation, 
machinery,  processing  of  cotton  and  other  products,  and  other  requirements. 3  Current 
investment is only about half that level. Seasonal financing requirements are about $90 million–
$100 million, of which 80% goes to cotton production. Current lending to the agriculture sector 
from  formal  financial  institutions  is  low;  formal  sector  lending  in  the  2005–2006  season  was 
estimated at about half the requirement. Growth in crop production, which was buoyed by low 
value food and cereal crops, will have to rely on a high valued and diversified crop mix.  
 
7. 
The most important policy recommendations that will enhance producer incentives and 
spur investments in the sector are: (i) farmers are given the freedom  to choose what to grow, 
how  to  grow  and  market  their  produce,  and  when  and  to  whom  they  can  sell  their  produce; 
(ii) farmers must have secured land use rights; and (iii) commodity and factor markets are free 
from  government  interference.  The  other  priority  agenda  for  moving  the  agriculture  sector 
forward is to address the poor performance of the cotton subsector.  
 
B. 
 
8. 
Production  Situation.  Cotton  continues  to  dominate  rural  life  and  provide  significant 
export income in Tajikistan. Cotton is grown on 50% of the country’s irrigated farmland. In 2004, 
the  cotton  subsector  provided  60%  of  the  value  of  total  agriculture  output,  75%  of  agriculture 
trade, 18% of total export receipts, and about 35% of tax revenues. Cotton incomes supported 
75% of farm households, and 75% of Tajikistan’s poor and extremely poor households. Data on 
output and yield in Table A2 demonstrate the decline in profitability. The decline in yields is due 
to a variety of economic and production factors discussed below.
