Manila. 

 

  

Appendix 2 

27

 

Cotton  production  is  concentrated  in  the  northern  Sughd  and  southern  Khatlon  oblasts 
9. 
(regions),  and  the  latter  produces  60%  of  the  total  crop.  Cotton  production  costs  $380/ha-
$580/ha.  In  around  15%  of  the  cases,  farmers  self-finance  or  borrow  from  banks  or  other 
institutions. The majority of farmers borrow from local traders, called investors.  
 
10. 
The  investors  supply  inputs  in-kind  during  the  planting  periods  of  March/April  and 
through the cultivation period until hand harvesting occurs in September/October. In return, the 
farmers  deliver  their  raw  cotton  to  a  predetermined  gin  for  processing,  and  repay  the  local 
investor for the loan by providing an agreed amount of raw cotton.   
 
11. 
Issues.  The  cotton  subsector  is  currently  underperforming.  At  the  farm  level,  average 
yield in 2005/06 is low at 1.55 tons per ha (tph), down from 2.80 tph in 1991. Current seasonal 
yield  is  1.25  tph  short  of  the  estimated  yield  level  required  to  ensure  that  cotton  farms  earn 
reasonable profits. Labor productivity has also fallen. It takes 250–350 person-hours to produce 
1 ton of seed cotton—more than four times the international competitive level of 70–80 person-
hours.4 Reversing these trends is critical to the success of cotton production in the country. 
 
12. 
Unprofitable  cotton  farms  are  inextricably  linked  to  poverty.  While  the  recent  positive 
growth  rates  experienced  by  Tajikistan  have  resulted  in  reduced  poverty  incidence,  the 
proportion of poor rural households remains highest in Sughd and Khatlon. About 72% of all the 
poor  in  the  country  and  75%  of  the  extreme  poor  live  in  these  two  regions.  Enhancing  cotton 
farm profitability is thus a priority agenda for alleviating rural income poverty in Tajikistan. 
 
13. 
The key performance issues and areas that must be addressed to improve Tajikistan’s 
cotton subsector production and profitability are numerous and interlinked. In the medium term, 
these  include  sector-wide  investment  and  policy  reforms,  such  as  (i)  irrigation  and  market 
infrastructure development, (ii) extension services, (iii) development of market-based seed and 
other  inputs  industries,  (iv)  gin  rehabilitation,  and  (v)  policies  promoting  crop  diversification.  In 
the immediate term, the most critical issues that need urgent response are the debt overhang, 
lack  of  financing  for  cotton,  and  the  monopolistic  and  rent-seeking  behavior  that  one-sided 
production  financing  arrangements  have  engendered.  Improvement  in  the  cotton  marketing 
practices  in  the  grading  system  and  mechanisms,  and  the  pricing  formula  can  provide  quick 
reprieve to an ailing cotton subsector. The areas that need immediate attention are as follows. 
 
14. 
Hukumat (District Government) and Cotton Production Forecasting. The system of 
central  planning  for  cotton  has  nominally  been  replaced  in  the  post-Soviet  period.  Each  year, 
the  Government  develops  national  and  raion  (district)  production  forecasts.  Chairpersons  of 
local  governments  (appointed  directly  by  the  President  of  Tajikistan)  are  held  accountable  for 
meeting the forecasts in their jurisdiction, and have been known to lose their positions if they fail 
to  meet  these  targets.  Additionally,  the  tax  system  provides  for  up-front  tax  revenues  from 
cotton,  and  these  collections  help  the  rais  (district  governor)  make  their  critical  tax  revenue 
targets.  All  of  these  factors  provide  powerful  incentives  for  local  governments  to  collude  with 
investors and require farmers to produce the maximum amount of cotton area using minimum 
inputs,  and  to  keep  all  sales  and  ginning  in  the  local  raion.  Local  governments  also  have  the 
capacity  to  revoke  farmers’  land  use  certificates  under  broad,  vaguely  defined  conditions  of 
“irrational land use,” thus providing them with considerable power over farmers. 
   
15. 
Debt  Overhang.  Defaulted  cotton  farm  debt  arising  from  the  lopsided  input  financing 
mechanism between the investor and the farm has accumulated since 1998 at a significant rate. 

                                                 
4 ADB. 2004. Farm Debt Resolution and Policy Reforms. Manila, p. 74. 

 

 28 

Appendix 2 

Total outstanding cotton production debt carryover from previous years’ loans was estimated by 
the  National  Bank  of  Tajikistan  (NBT)  at  $292.8  million  in  2006—equivalent  to  over  three  full 
seasons of financing and roughly equal to the government operations budget for a year.  Debt 
per ha ranges from less than $500 to over $8,000. About 9% of indebted farms, covering 15% of 
the total cotton area, have debt of over $1,500 per ha.  
 
16. 
Lenders  have  not  responded  to  the  usual  market  signals  of  non-repayment  by  slowing 
down cotton-farm lending, and there have been no efforts by lenders or borrowers to consider 
farms’  capacity  to  repay  on  a  sustainable  basis.  Investor  practices  exacerbating  farm  debt 
rollover include oversupply; over-invoicing and overpricing of inputs supplied; inadequate timing 
and  quality  of  inputs;  locking  in  farmers  by  placing  liens  from  prior  debts  on  current  cotton 
production;  and  constant  rollover  of  unpaid  debts  and  annual  capitalization  of  unpaid  interest 
plus  penalties.  Lack  of  accountability  of  farm  association  managers  and  accountants  to  farm 
owners and members for farm financial arrangements has also aggravated the problem. Lastly, 
there  was  lack  of  NBT  supervision  over  KreditInvest,  the  nonfinancial  institution  that  provided 
credit sources to the majority of investors.  
 
17. 
Failure to penalize lenders for this malpractice was due in part to the local governments’ 
need for investors to provide input financing for cotton production—the income source of their 
tax  quota  allotment,  which  if  met,  is  the  basis  for  their  political  survival.  The  hukumats  thus 
require  farmers  not  only  to  plant  cotton  on  70%  of  their  farmland  but  to  (i)  obtain  their  crop 
financing needs only from the district-designated investor, and (ii) process their produce in the 
district-designated gin. The one-investor policy of the hukumats ensures lopsided conditions on 
the production contract arrangements in favor of the local investor.  
 
18. 
External factors also contributed to the accumulation of debt, among them the decline in 
the  world  prices  for  fiber  cotton  and  the  increase  in  the  prices  of  vital  inputs  used  by  the 
subsector,  such  as  fuel,  fertilizer,  and  minerals.  Because  of  the  heavy  debt  levels  and  related 
market  restrictions,  lending  to  the  agricultural  sector  through  financial  institutions  is  effectively 
frozen.  Alternative  financing  support  from  international  financial  organizations  and  external 
private  sector  will  not  be  possible  unless  cotton  farm  debt  is  resolved  in  a  transparent  and 
voluntary manner between creditors and farmers.  
 
19. 
There  are  currently  no  viable  alternatives  to  investor  credit  for  the  cotton  subsector  in 
Tajikistan. The banking sector in the country is extremely small, with a loan to GDP ratio of just 
4.5% and a deposit to GDP ratio of 4.0%. Most of its credit resources go to industry (40%) and 
commerce  (40%),  with  only  10%  going  to  agriculture.  Formal  financial  institutions  are  highly 
cautious  in  lending  to  agriculture  ventures  because  of  the  high  transaction  costs  entailed  in 
providing credit to farmer clients, the lack of farm assets for collateral, the moral hazard, and the 
risky environment and uncertainty of agriculture production.        
 
20. 
Farm  Restructuring  in  Tandem  with  Farm  Debt  Allocation.  The  farm  restructuring 
process has resulted in an increase of cotton farms, from 658 farms at year-end 2002 to over 
22,000  farms  in  late  2005.  There  has  been  no  systemic  attention  given  to  farm  management 
needs, or to the reassignment or assumption of public or private farm debt obligations. Under a 
Presidential  Decree,  private  debt  was  reassigned  on  a  per-irrigated  hectare  basis  after 
consideration  of  machinery  and  other  non-land  asset  distribution.  As  of  1  October  2005, 
approximately  61%  of  restructured  farms  have  signed  debt  reallocation  agreements,  and  the 
process is ongoing. However, the  debt reallocation process was undertaken without reviewing 
the accuracy of debt and reference to the new farm’s capacity to repay the assigned debt. This 

 

  

Appendix 2 

29

 

will undoubtedly complicate investor capacity to engage with and manage farm debtors, and will 
significantly increase the size and complexity of farm debt resolution.   
 
21. 
Cotton Processing and Marketing. The systems in Tajikistan for the collection of seed 
cotton  and  its  processing  are  weak,  and  involve  monopolistic  market  arrangements  and 
interventionist  policies.  The  most  important  impediments  are  the  poor  cotton  grading  and 
marketing systems, underpricing and undervaluation of baled cotton, and gin inefficiencies. 
 
The current cotton classification and grading standard systems inadequately determine 
22. 
the quality of the commodity, thus lowering the price received by farmers for their seed cotton 
and fiber cotton. Current Tajikstandard classification and practices in the grading of cotton5 do 
not adequately reflect the quality of cotton and the price differential that can be obtained in the 
marketplace. A new approach to classification and issuance of grade certificates is required to 
increase the confidence of external buyers in the quality of the cotton sold and to improve the 
price of Tajik baled cotton.  
 
Although there are 54 privately-owned gins6 in the country, most gins have low outturn 
23. 
averages  and  are  underutilized.  The  ongoing  inefficiencies  of  gins  are  largely  due  to  lack  of 
competition  as  a  result  of  the  restricted  movement  of  cotton  between  districts.  Farmers  are 
unable  to  shift  their  seed  cotton  to  another  gin  because  of  taxation  arrangements  for  local 
governments.   
 
24. 
Gin  operators  are  also  the  investors  who  lend  to  farmers,  and  because  of  their 
monopsinistic  position,  they  are  able  to  buy  seed  cotton  on  a  heavily  discounted  basis  and 
manipulate  cotton  grades  in  favor  of  the  ginner.  Gin  operators  make  payment  to  farmers  only 
after fiber cotton is shipped and funds are received from foreign buyers (6–7 months or longer 
after  receipt  of  the  raw  cotton).  They  retain  ginning  by-products  which  should  be  returned  to 
farmers (or paid for).  
 
25. 
The pricing formula exerts a downward push on the price of baled cotton. Tajik cotton is 
sold on the basis of lots (1 lot is approximately 50 tons) rather than individual bales; this further 
underprices  cotton,  as  the  price  is  based  on  the  lowest  grade  of  cotton  in  a  blended  lot.  The 
present lot system results in at least 4% loss of the true value or at least $4,000 per 50 ton lot.  
 
26. 
Recent Steps to Improve Subsector. The Government has responded to the daunting 
challenges of  an  underperforming  cotton  subsector,  accumulating  debt,  and  pervasive  poverty 
in  the  subsector.  In  March  2005,  the  President  of  Tajikistan  approved  the  Cotton  Farm  Debt 
Resolution  Strategy  (CFDRS).  The  strategy  has  a  two-pronged  approach:  (i)  resolving  the 
immediate and urgent problem of a huge debt overhang through the facilitation of debt workouts 
between  private  lenders  and  private  borrowers  to  ensure  fair  and  equitable  resolution  of  the 
debt  on  a  farm-by-farm  basis;  and  (ii)  a  medium-term  policy  as  well  as  legal  and  institutional 
measures  that  will  enable  a  properly  functioning  cotton  market.  The  proposed  policy  reforms 
include  (i) removal  of  the  cotton  plan  system  and  implicit  quotas;  (ii)  secure  land  tenure;  (iii) 
international grading standards; (iv) giving farmers freedom to choose what to grow and where 
to  sell;  and  (v) creating  a  competitive,  market-driven  agricultural  lending  system.  The  strategy 
calls for the establishment of an Independent Commission (IC) to oversee implementation.

On 13 February 2006, ADB and World Bank officials met with the President of Tajikistan. 
During this meeting, ADB and the World Bank expressed the view that the rapid transformation 
of Tajikistan’s cotton subsector is possible by focusing attention and actions in five key areas: 
 

Debt  resolution.  Cotton  farm  debts  must  be  analyzed  and  the  debt  resolution 
plans  developed  on  a  farm-by-farm  basis,  and  through  transparent  and 
participatory approaches based on farmers’ capacity to repay.  

financing  oversight.  A

Farmers’ freedom to choose. Farmers must be able to make fundamental farm

F. 
 
The  above  sector  constraints  have  a  profound  impact  on  the  livelihoods  of  the  rural 
30. 
farmers  in  Tajikistan.  Compared  with  other  sectors  of  the  economy,  incomes  from  agriculture 
are very low and it is estimated that rural incomes have dropped to less than 5% of urban wage 
rates.  The  increasing  disparity  has  resulted  in  a  paradoxical  situation  of  falling  rural  incomes 
while  the  farm  sector  increasingly  absorbs  a  high  proportion  of  the  growth  in  the  working 
population.  Furthermore,  the  private  agribusiness  sector  remains  poorly  developed,  largely 
because  of  the  unclear  business  environment.  Private  rural  businesses  involved  in  trading, 
processing, or construction activities are generally limited to small-scale operations with modest 
capital investment. 
 
31. 
The  main  binding  constraint  to  be  addressed  by  the  Project  is  the  current  system  of 
incentives, particularly  the  farm  debt  overhang,  state  production  quota and  the  restrictive  crop 
procurement,  and  poor  marketing  and  pricing  policies  and  facilities.  Reforms  in  these  policies 
and  practices  will  provide  sufficient  motivation  and  freedom  of  choice  to  private  farmers  to 
increase  investments  in  their  land  so  that  they  can  realize  productivity  gains,  implement  more 
sustainable cropping systems, and choose higher value products.

3. 
A  key  aspect  of  processing  has  been  the  consultative  process  initiated  by  ADB 
(Supplementary  Appendix  L).  A  three-day  executive  retreat  was  held  in  June  2005  involving

for the Cotton Farm Debt Resolution Strategy, later confirmed by the President of Tajikistan; (ii) 
a  vision  statement  and  a  mission  statement;  and  (iii)  improved  guiding  principles,  terms  of 
reference, and organizational structure for the IC.

A related advisory TA for enabling farm debt resolution processes was designed in April

until  March  2006  and  the  requirement  for  14  consultants  to  be  individually  selected  has 
somewhat slowed its progress. However, lessons from this TA can be easily fed into the Project. 
 
5. 
In  order  to  address  issues  of  poor  households  in  a  more  substantive  way,  a  related 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) project has been planned. The objective of the JFPR 
grant (Increasing Sustainable Income of Cotton Farm workers) is threefold: (i) to provide funding 
for  poor  cotton  farm  workers  who  are  predominantly  women,  to  enhance  farm-based  incomes 
via  microfinance  lending;  (ii)  to  improve  the  engagement  of  poor  households  in  cotton 
processing operations and management; and (iii) to improve the ability of cotton farm workers to 
manage  investments  through  capacity  building  training.  An  application  for  seed  grant  funding 
was successfully undertaken in December 2005. The formal application, expected to be for $3.0 
million, will be made by November 2006. 
 
Aid coordination and cooperation have also been critical elements in loan processing, as 
6. 
the  farm  debt  resolution  and  cotton  subsector  reform  will  require  joint  engagement  by  a  wide 
variety  of  donors  with  significant  resources  to  be  successful.  Multi-donor  consultations  on  the 
project  concept,  fit  with  existing  and  planned  activities,  and  the  potential  for  parallel  financing 
were  explored  during  all  four  missions.  The  memorandum  of  agreement  from  the  loan  fact-
finding  was presented  to  the  IC  and  16  donors,  and  ongoing  parallel project  on  the  Economic 
Cotton Sector Recovery and Poverty Reduction is under way with the World Bank.  
 
Lastly, the Government showed strong commitment to ensuring a sustainable resolution 
7. 
of  farm  debt.  In  2006,  The  President  of  Tajikistan  spearheaded  quarterly  meetings  including 
himself, cabinet officials, and senior management of ADB and the World Bank (Supplementary

ADF IX GRANT COMPONENT 
 

Constraints to Growth and Poverty Reduction  

1. 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  provide  financing  of  $12  million  for  the 
Sustainable Cotton Subsector Project. From this total, the Government is requesting an Asian 
Development  Fund  (ADF)  IX  grant  of  $6.5  million  to  finance  the  following:  (i)  a  farm  debt 
workout  and  resolution  process  for  four  raions  (districts)  in  Khatlon  and  Sughd;  (ii)  public 
outreach on farm debt resolution; (iii) policy reforms on farm debt resolution, poverty reduction, 
and market development; (iv) training of key agencies and stakeholders on the adoption of the 
universal  cotton  grading  system;  and  (v)  funding  of  the  operations  of  the  Common  Center  for 
Project Management (CCfPM). This appendix discusses the rationale, purpose, and activities of 
the Project’s grant-funded components.  
 
A. 
 
2. 
 Fiscal  Weakness  and  Narrow  Economic  Base.  At  the  macro  level,  Tajikistan  has 
accumulated a massive external debt. Despite improvements in managing the fiscal deficit, the 
Government  faces  significant  structural  impediments  that  limit  its  capacity  to  invest  in  basic 
social services and infrastructure, and prevent the Government from initiating poverty reducing 
measures.  One  major  structural  bottleneck  is  its  limited  revenue  sources.  The  Government 
relies mainly on its narrow export base (aluminum, cotton, and hydropower) for tax receipts. In 
past  years,  the  cotton  subsector  alone  generated  about  35%  of  tax  revenues. 1 For  the 
Government  to  address  its  fiscal  situation,  the  economy  must  diversify  its  income  generating 
activities and improve the performance of its existing revenue sources.  
 
Underperforming  Cotton  Subsector.  The  cotton  subsector  dominates  the  agriculture 
3. 
sector but it is performing at suboptimal levels. At the farm level, average yield in 2005 was a 
low 1.55 tons per ha (tph) and was 1.25 tph short of the estimated yield level required for cotton 
farms  to  earn  reasonable  profits.  Labor  productivity  has  also  fallen.  It  takes  250–350  person-
hours to produce 1 ton of seed cotton, or more than four times the international competitive level 
of  70–80  person-hours.2 Input  use  has  been  suboptimal  because  of  untimely  delivery  of  vital 
inputs, a rise in input costs, poor input quality, and lack of access to appropriate forms of credit. 
Irrigation  facilities  have  deteriorated  and  service  delivery  has  been  inefficient.  Improper  water 
and  land  use,  salinity,  and  waterlogging  problems  have  worsened;  and  land  quality  has 
declined.  
 
4. 
Farm  Debt.  A  major  factor  for  the underperformance  of  the  subsector  is  the  huge  and 
unresolved  debt  of  cotton  farms  with  their  creditors  (referred  to  as  “investors”).  Farms  mainly 
access  inputs,  credit,  and  cotton  income  from  the  investors  through  the  practice  of  annual 
production contract arrangements. However, the contracts are lopsided and prone to extraction 
of  illicit  rents  in  favor  of  the  investor.  In  addition,  when  operated  in  an  unfavorable  business 
environment,  the  circumstances  tend  to  further  discourage  farms  to  become  more  productive 
and  other  economic  players  to  become  efficient.  The  prognosis  for  economic  recovery  of  the 
subsector  is  bleak,  as  debt  has  been  accumulating.  Total  outstanding  cotton  production  debt 
carryover from previous years’ loans was estimated by the National Bank of Tajikistan (NBT) at 
$292.8  million  in  2006.  The  cotton  subsector  needs  immediate  assistance  to  resolve  its  debt 
through  an  objective  debt  assessment  using  a  variety  of  indebted  farm  cases  and  eventually, 
the development of protocols and procedures for resolving the debt on a subsector-wide basis.

Sources  of  Market  Failures  and  Distortions.  Sustainable resolution of the farm debt 
5. 
problem requires addressing the symptom (i.e., debt at the farm level) as well as the root cause 
(government  interference).  Full  economic  recovery  of  the  subsector  will  need  the  removal  of 
government  interventions  that  distort  the  key  operations  in  the  subsector’s  value  chain  and 
make the chain ineffective. Without freedom to decide farm production and marketing choices—
because the hukumat (district government) controls land use rights—farmers have no incentive 
to become productive. Monopsonies3 in production credit and processing further reduce the net 
returns that accrue to farmers. Policy reforms are essential and will need to be addressed jointly 
with  the  farm  debt  resolution  exercise.  Initiating  reforms  will  also  require  effective  advocacy 
through continuous dialogue, public awareness raising, and the use of mass media. 
 
6. 
Constraints  in  Capacities.  One  of  the  main  priorities  is  to  establish  an  efficient, 
integrated, and cohesive cotton supply chain. To move toward this, the Project intends to work 
on  the  root  cause  for  and  the  symptom  of  farm  debt.  It  also  intends  to  invest  in  building  the 
technical capacities required by the Independent Commission (IC) to decide and initiate policy 
reforms that effectively address the structural constraints afflicting the cotton subsector and the 
agriculture  sector  in  general.  These  technical  skills  will  be  needed  by  the  CCfPM  that  will  link 
the  Project  to  the  IC.  Other  technical  skills  that  will  be  required  are  those  that  ensure  the 
adoption  of  universal  cotton  grading  standards,  development  of  business  plans,  promotion  of 
producers’  organizations,  effective  production  contract  arrangements,  and  other  agreements 
that will enable farmers to enhance their economic returns from cotton production.    
 
7. 
Balancing  Act.  The  interventions  in  the  cotton  subsector  require  a  strategic  balancing 
act. On one hand, they have to pave the way for immediate sustainable broad-based growth; on 
the  other  hand,  they  should  not  negatively  impact  on  the  present  role  of  cotton  as  a  major 
source of government revenue and of employment and income to the vast majority of the rural 
poor.  Measures  will  need  to  be  developed  that  will  (i)  resolve  the  cotton  farm  debt  issue  and 
provide  reform  measures  that  prevent  debt  from  recurring;  and  (ii)  address  the  farm  debt 
resolution  jointly  with  measures  that  will  remove  the  causes  of  market  distortions  in  both  the 
upstream  and  downstream  aspects  of  the  cotton  supply  chain.  A  more  market-driven 
environment  in  the  cotton  subsector  will  minimize  inefficiencies  caused  by  market  distortions 
and the huge transaction costs that arise from the rent-seeking behavior of some actors in the 
cotton  value  chain.  This  new  environment  will  provide  farms  the  leverage  to  intensify  their 
production as well as diversify their crop mix and income-generating opportunities.  
 
B. 
 
8. 
The  grant  component  of  the  Project  proposes  to  address  the  pressing  problems  of  the 
cotton subsector that adversely affect its economic performance and its strategic role in poverty 
reduction, in a manner that will have minimal impact on the fiscal function of the Government. 
Therefore,  priority  will  be  given  to  developing  a  sustainable  debt  resolution  strategy  and  an 
improved marketing environment and capacity for the cotton subsector without exacerbating the 
still precarious financial position of the Government.

Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 

 
Is  the  sector  identified  as  a  national  priority

A. 
 
Is the sector identified as a national 
priority in country poverty analysis?   
 
Contribution  of  the  sector  or  subsector  to  reduce  poverty  in  the  Republic  of  Tajikistan:  Sustainable 
cotton subsector development will contribute significantly to reducing rural poverty in Tajikistan. Cotton farming 
is the major income source for rural households in Khatlon and Sughd, the two main cotton producing oblasts 
(regions) in Tajikistan that in 2003 were home to 72% of the poor and 75% of the extremely poor.1  
 
Sustained growth in cotton value is vital for significantly reducing the incidence of poverty in the country. It is 
also  crucial  in  spurring  aggregate  broad-based  growth  of  the  agriculture  sector  in  particular  and  the  national 
economy  in  general.  Cotton  is  grown  on  60%  of  the  country’s  irrigated  farmland,  and  the  cotton subsector  in 
2004  generated  60%  of  the  value  of  total  agriculture  output  and  is  the  largest  employer  of  Tajikistan’s  rural 
labor force. It is the primary export crop of the agriculture sector, accounting for 75–90% of agriculture exports. 
Cotton, fruits, vegetables, and aluminum constitutes  40% of the country’s gross domestic product (GDP) and 
70% of export earnings. The cotton subsector generated 35% of tax revenues.   
 
The  growth  of  Tajikistan’s  cotton  subsector  has  not  been  pro-poor.  The  decline  in  poverty  observed  in  the 
growth years of 1998–2003 was due to the remittances generated by migrant workers, and to the lower relative 
prices of food and other main expenditure items of the rural populace. The impact of improvements in cotton 
yield and output value from 1998 to 2003 on poverty reduction was insignificant. A World Bank study (Abdulai, 
A. 2005. Agriculture and Poverty under Economic Reforms in Tajikistan. Washington, D.C World Bank.) noted 
that a 10% increase in yield and output value of cotton resulted in a mere 1.5% reduction in poverty.  
 
Poverty  reduction  during  these  growth  years  was  lowest  in  Khatlon  (15%)  and  Sughd  (13%)  relative  to  the 
national poverty reduction rate of 20%. The probability of being poor is higher in the two cotton-growing areas 
than in other oblasts. Khatlon alone, which has a third of the country’s population, accounts for more than half 
of the total number of extremely poor households in Tajikistan. Inequality is also most severe in Khatlon and it 
has  even  worsened  from  1999  to  2003.  The  root  cause  of  income  poverty  in  Khatlon  and  Sughd,  where  the 
majority  of  the  poor  resides,  is  the  underperformance  of  the  cotton  subsector.  This  subsector  is 
underperforming  because  of  (i)  huge  farm  debt  that  has  paralyzed  credit  and  investment  generation  to  the 
subsector, and (ii) structural bottlenecks that induce market distortions in the cotton’s supply value chain and 
reduce the income of cotton farms. Reversing the poor economic performance of cotton farms is thus a priority 
agenda  for  alleviating  rural  income  poverty  in  Tajikistan.  At  present,  migration  to  non-poor  regions  or  to  the 
Russian Federation and wealthier neighboring countries is the main way the poor use to exit from poverty.  
 
B. Poverty Analysis  

Targeting Classification: General intervention 

 

What type of poverty analysis is needed? The poverty analysis for this Project focused on an assessment of 
income  poverty  from  the  perspective  of  (i)  low-income  cotton  farm  households;  and  (ii)  vulnerable  groups, 
including cotton farm workers, women farm workers and farmers, and child labor during the cotton harvesting 
seasons. 
 
Low-Income  Cotton  Farmers. Cotton has a strategic role in generating fiscal revenues, so the Government 
has maintained a strong grip on the key operations in the subsector’s value chain. A production quota for cotton 
is  targeted  annually  and  local  governments  ensure  that  the  targets  are  met.  Cotton  farmers  do  not  have  the 
freedom to decide what to produce in their farmland, where to buy their inputs, and where to sell their produce. 
Key  production  decisions  at  the  farm  level  are  under  the  control  of  the  local  governments,  exercised  through 
their  authority  to  allocate  and  confiscate  agricultural  land  from  the  farmers  on  the  basis  of  vaguely  worded 
criteria  such  as  “irrational  land  use.”  Farmers,  too,  are  confined  to  obtaining  credit  only  from  investors 
designated by local governments, and are bound to have their produce processed in gins designated by local 
                                                 
1   The poverty line used to define the poor in the World Bank study was purchasing power parity (PPP) $2.15 a day, 
while the poverty line for the extremely poor was PPP $1.08 a day. The 2000 PPP conversion rate was employed 
in  defining  these  thresholds.  These  poverty  definitions  were  complemented  by  self-assessment  of  poverty 
situations  through  interviews  and  focus  group  discussions.  (World  Bank.  2005.  Poverty  Assessment  Update- 
Republic of Tajikistan. Washington DC: World Bank). 

 

  

Appendix 6 

39

 

governments. Because of lack of competition from credit sources for inputs and gin processing, farmers incur 
numerous  implicit  rents,  such  as  overpriced  low  quality  inputs,  untimely  delivery  of  these  inputs,  processing 
time  in  excess  of  200  days,  under-grading  of  seed  cotton,  poor  storage  facilities  in  gins,  and  underpricing  of 
fiber cotton. Profits are squeezed from the farmers, who then accumulate debt ranging from $500 per hectare 
(ha) to more than $8,000/ha. Debt accumulation and structural constraints served as disincentives to farmers to 
become  productive.  The  overall  impact  on  the  subsector  is  devastating.  In  2005,  cotton  production  further 
declined to 447,922 tons, and yield plummeted to 1.55 tons per ha. 
 
Farmers hardly get any share of the benefits from the downstream activities of the supply chain. Instead, they 
bear  the  costs,  including  those  brought  about  by  the  delays  in  the  receipt  of  their  revenues  from  fiber  cotton 
and by the inappropriate grading and classification of fiber cotton. The value of seed cotton to ex-gin gate price 
is just 26%, while the value share of the cost, insurance, freight (CIF) price of fiber cotton to the free on board 
(FOB) price of fiber cotton is 52%. This is much lower than what the Australian farmer receives, which is 90–
92%.    
 
A study correlating productivity with poverty reduction showed a weak relation between the two, implying that 
increased yield would not be sufficient to lift poor cotton farm households out of poverty. What is required are 
higher  economic  returns  arising  from  more  transparent  and  competitive  access  to  agriculture  finance,  lower 
costs of inputs, timely delivery of the right amounts of quality inputs, fair prices for farm produce, a level playing 
field  for  gin  owners,  and  freedom  for  farmers  to  diversify  their  income  sources  through  best  crop  mix  and 
access to off-farm employment.  
   
Farm  Workers  and  Women.  Cotton  farm  workers  are  another  disadvantaged  group  in  the  subsector.  They 
constitute the bulk of the rural labor force and the rural poor. They are paid dismally low wages. In 2004, wages 
for planting and preparatory work ranged from only $0.40–$2.00 per month per worker; for picking seed cotton 
by hand, payment was only $0.02–0.03 per kilogram (kg).  
 
More than 75% of the estimated 400,000 farm workers in the subsector are women. A large number of the rural 
male labor force has migrated to the Russian Federation and Kazakhstan to increase their household income. 
In 2003, 41% of migrant workers in the former Soviet Union were from Khatlon. Thus, farm work is left mainly to 
female-headed  households,  the  elderly,  and  the  young.  With  hardly  any  off-farm  and  nonfarm  employment 
opportunities, female farm workers have no option but to continue working on cotton farms while fulfilling their 
household  responsibilities.  Working  in  cotton  farms  enables  them  to  access  garden  plots,  averaging  0.1–0.3 
ha,  where  they  grow  their  food  and  other  crops  to  be  sold  in  the  market.  The  other  incentive  of  working  on 
cotton farms is that they can collect ghuzpoya (dried cotton bush or stalks used for cooking and heating during 
winter). The women workforce in the subsector has less opportunity for holding key management positions in 
cotton  farms.  Less  than  5%  of  managers  in  the  cotton  farm  associations  are  women,  although  an  estimated 
65% of farmers and more than 75% of farm workers are women. 
 
A study concluded that a 10% increase in cotton wages would significantly reduce poverty by as much as 3%. 
This impact would be much higher than the impact of seed cotton yield improvements on poverty. However, an 
increase  in  wages  can  only  be  sustained  if  the  indebted  cotton  farms  become  financially  viable  economic 
enterprises. There is a need to address the structural impediments in the production and marketing aspects of 
the cotton value chain that hamper the overall sustainable development of the cotton subsector. Because of the 
large composition of women involved in the cotton subsector labor force, there is also a need for broad-based, 
growth-enhancing measures that address the needs of women farm workers and farmers.   
 
Child  Labor.  Minors  (8–14  years),  together  with  employees  from  the  public  and  private  sectors,  are  also 
employed especially during harvesting season. Even during Tajikistan’s pre-independence years, all available 
hands in the country were used to work in the cotton farms. Coupled with the scarcity of income opportunities, 
this nonmarket labor recruitment network has become an acceptable working norm. School classes and formal 
work  from  public  and  private  institutions  are  disrupted  during  the  harvest  period.  Schoolchildren  are  sent  to 
cotton fields each year, live in badly equipped and cramped barracks while  working in the fields, get minimal 
subsistence allowance, and get paid on an output basis after the harvest. Anecdotal cases have documented 
harsh  working  conditions  such  as  long  working  hours  under  the  summer  heat,  which  can  rise  to  100° 
Fahrenheit;  health  problems  (from  exhaustion  to  intestinal  and  respiratory  infections);  and  low  remuneration 
that leads to debt.  
 
Addressing the problem of employing child labor in the cotton subsector cannot be resolved overnight. A long-
lasting  solution  to  this  concern  is  inextricably  linked  to  ensuring  broad-based  and  sustainable  growth  of  the 

 

 40 

Appendix 6 

cotton subsector. A more robust subsector will pay farm workers better, open more livelihood and job options 
within and outside the cotton subsector, and reduce the economic necessity of engaging child and adolescent 
labor during the cotton harvesting season.  
 
Poverty Reduction Strategy of the Project. The impact of the Project is the development of an economically 
sustainable  cotton  subsector  in  Tajikistan’s  two  major  cotton-producing  regions,  Khatlon  and  Sughd.  A  key 
indicator to achieving this impact is that income poverty in these regions would have been reduced by 2015 to 
26% for Khatlon and 24% for Sughd. To lay the foundation for the reduction of poverty in the cotton subsector, 
the  Project’s  interventions  will  address  the  farm  debt  in  four  raions  (districts),  provide  alternative  financing 
products  and  services  to  restructured  farms,  and  ensure  market  development  at  the  downstream  side  of  the 
supply value chain. Policy reforms will reduce the producers’ disincentive to produce efficiently, minimize illicit 
rents,  and  enhance  quality  and  pricing  of  both  seed  cotton  and  fiber  cotton.  These  broad-based  growth-
enhancing measures at strategic levels of the supply chain will be complemented with proactive measures that 
(i) address the income poverty of low-income indebted cotton farms; (ii) tackle the vulnerability of farm workers, 
especially female farm workers and farmers; and (iii) create incentives to reduce the use of child labor during 
harvesting season. In the farm debt workout and resolution process, preference will be accorded to small-sized 
farmland  users  and  women  farmers  with  low-income  returns  at  or  below  the  poverty  threshold,  farms  with  a 
large number of poor to extremely poor farm workers, and farm households headed by females. Potential areas 
for improving incomes derived from cotton farm production that will be explored are: (i) decreases in the illicit 
costs caused by lopsided contract agreements; (ii) improved yield arising from increased producer’s incentives; 
(iii) improved pricing of seed cotton, and returns from the by-products, and (iv) higher shares due to increased 
efficiency  in  fiber  cotton  processing  and  marketing  and  distribution.  The  other  potential  area  for  improving 
incomes  is  the  opportunity  of  farmers  to  diversify  their  crop  mix,  thus  reducing  their  dependence  on  cotton 
monoculture  production.  This  will  arise  from  the  removal  of  hukumat  (district  government)  intervention  in  the 
farms’ production and decision-making process.  
 
Farm  debt  resolution  will  take  into  account  the  social  and  poverty  implications  and  will  ensure  that  mitigation 
measures  are  included  in  the  resolution  agreements  to  address  these  issues.  For  farms  that  are  declared 
bankrupt, the resolution agreements will include mitigation measures to minimize adverse implications on poor 
farm households and vulnerable groups employed in the farms. Business plans of restructured farms that have 
undergone  and  completed  the  farm  debt  resolution  process  will  include  mitigation  measures  to  avert  any 
adverse implications on the well-being of vulnerable groups during the transition years toward recovery. 
 
Awareness  raising  of  the  rights  of  farmers,  women,  and  children  will  be  incorporated  in  the  public  outreach 
activities  of  the  Project.  Policy  studies  on  concerns  of  cotton  farmers,  women  farm  workers  and  use  of  child 
labor will be conducted to provide mitigating measures that can be acted upon by the Independent Commission 
(IC). To raise awareness and encourage social discourse among these stakeholders, regular feedback will be 
provided to the IC on such monitoring indicators as poverty and the risks and vulnerability of women farmers 
and farm workers and child labor. 
 
Because of the significant gender dimension and high poverty situation among farm workers, a separate Japan 
Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)  project  is  being  developed  in  tandem  with  the  Project.  The  JFPR  project 
will  provide  direct  microfinance  access  to  women  to  broaden  their  income  opportunities,  and  provide  training 
and capacity building on technical, financial and empowerment skills.    
            
Method  of  Poverty  Analysis  and  Monitoring  the  Results. A more rigorous stakeholder assessment will be 
undertaken in the pilot raions during the inception mission and will be verified at least twice a year during the 
Project’s  implementation  period.  The  assessment  at  the  initial  stage  will  look  at  stakeholders’  interests  in 
maintaining and changing the status quo in the cotton subsector operations, the nature and degree of political 
influence at the raion and national levels, and the options for minimizing conflicts. Indicators will be developed 
for  the  major  target  beneficiaries  using  a participatory  approach.  This  will  be  followed  through  the  conduct  of 
stakeholder  assessments  on  a  semiannual  basis.  In  the  process,  early  warning  signals  will  be  devised  for 
consideration by the IC that will forewarn policy makers in the event that the poverty situation of the vulnerable 
groups is threatened by external and internal factors.   
 
At the project level, farm-by-farm analysis will be done in a participatory manner, involving key stakeholders in 
the farm debt. The analysis will include documentation of the poverty, risks, and vulnerability profile of farmers 
and farm workers by gender, as well as the use of child and adolescent labor.  
 
For each project output, monitoring indicators that relate the Project’s performance on the poor and vulnerable 

 

  

Appendix 6 

41

 

groups in the project areas will be determined in a participatory manner during the stakeholder dialogues at the 
inception phase of project implementation. Benchmark data will be gathered and disaggregated by gender and 
by  age  and  according  to  the  targeted  vulnerable  groups.  The  Common  Center  for  Project  Management  will 
provide regular feedback to the IC on the  progress of the poverty-related assessments and indicators for the 
different vulnerable groups. 
 
To measure the impact of the Project on the poverty and vulnerability of the poor and vulnerable groups, the 
value chain analysis will be employed to identify the foregone value and volume of seed cotton and fiber cotton 
that  should  have  accrued  (Appendix  11).  This  value  chain  analysis  will  also  be  the  basis  for  determining  the 
employment and revenue losses to key stakeholders resulting from policy and institutional practices that induce 
market distortions. The use of a qualified transmission channel approach will complement this type of analysis. 
This approach will be employed to assess the distributional impact on income and relevant non-income poverty 
of the intervention measures.  
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
A preliminary stakeholder analysis was done to determine the key stakeholders at the cotton farm production 
phase (Supplementary Appendix M). Another stakeholder assessment was done during the fact-finding mission 
to  determine  the  major  players  in  the  downstream  (marketing)  aspects  of  the  supply  value  chain 
(Supplementary Appendix L).  
 
Is there a participation strategy? 
The  participatory  strategy  will  be  developed  during  the  inception  mission  in  tandem  with  the  stakeholder 
assessment.  
 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy  to  maximize  impacts  on  women:  Because  of  the  dominant  role  that  women  play  in  the  cotton 
subsector, the Project puts strong emphasis on the active participation of women in the implementation phase. 
During  implementation,  consultation  processes  in  the  four  raions  for  the  farm  debt  resolution  component  will 
take into account women’s involvement. Indebted farms that are headed by women will be given priority in the 
farm-by-farm analysis.  Representation of indebted farms that are run by  women and of  women  farm workers 
will  be  ensured  during  policy  dialogues  with  national  and  local  governments.  A  gender  action  plan  will  be 
developed during project implementation.  
 
The  economic  benefits  of  the  market  development  component  will  accrue  to  both  male  and  female  cotton-
growing  farmers.  However,  to  ensure  that  benefits  of  this  component  are  gender-neutral,  a  monitoring  and 
evaluation system will be developed, and the starting point will be the determination of gender-disaggregated 
performance indicators for all project components.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 

International Consultants 

 
1. 
A  total  of  1,269  person-months  of  consulting  services  will  be  required,  comprising  62 
person-months  of  international  consultants  and  1,207  person-months  of  national  consultants. 
Funds have been reserved in the budget for additional consulting time if and when required by 
the Government and agreed with Asian Development Bank (ADB).  Detailed terms of reference 
are in Supplementary Appendix N. 
 
A. 
 
2. 
The  international  consultant  will  hold  a  graduate  degree  or  its  equivalent  in  an  area 
relevant  to  the  expertise  required.  They  should  have  at  least  10  years  of  international 
development  work  experience  and  actual  work  experience  in  tasks  specified  in  the  terms  of 
reference  (TOR).  A  background  in  rural  development  in  transition  economies  and/or  work 
experience  in  cotton  industry  is  an  advantage.  Strong  skills  in  written  and  spoken  English  are 
required. 
 
3. 
Agricultural  Debt  Workout  Specialist/Team  Leader  (24  person-months).  The 
consultant will (i) lead in the development of standardized protocols and procedures for the farm 
debt resolution; (ii) develop the methodology for the conduct of farm-by-farm analysis and farm 
debt  resolution  processes;  (ii)  lead  in  the  development  of  the  farm  debt  resolution  manual  for 
replication on a subsector-wide basis; (iii) oversee the policy work for the farm debt resolution, 
market development, and agricultural finance components; and (iv) ensure that the Government 
adheres to the assurances as laid out in the Project. 
 
4. 
Legal  Advisor  (4  person-months).  The  consultant  will  (i) provide  legal  guidance on  all 
aspects of the Project, including land tenure and security of agricultural land rights, civil law and 
contracts,  bankruptcy,  and  tax;  (ii)  provide  technical  support  to  mobile  and  negotiating  teams 
based  in  raions  (districts)  on  resolving  sophisticated  legal  issues;  (iii)  prepare  policy  position 
papers and draft legislation and government resolutions on farm debt matters; and (iv) assist in 
developing model agreements and the farm debt resolution manual.  
 
Negotiations Specialist (3 person-months). The consultant will (i) lead initial training of

negotiating  the  resolution  of  complex  issues;  and  (iii)  ensure  the  effectiveness  of  national 
professional staff in negotiating settlements of cotton debt of farms included in the program.   

 
6. 
Farm  Management  Specialist  (4  person-months).  The  consultant  will  (i)  design  the 
framework,  methodology,  and  procedure  for  farm  budget  analysis,  as  well  as  for  the 
development  of  farm  business  model  plans  of  different  farm  debt  situations  and  varied 
agronomic  conditions;  (ii)  identify  the  viability  of  the  development  of  producer  organizations 
among restructured farms and evaluate the feasibility of venture options for restructured farms 
and mitigation measures for bankrupt farms; (iii) assist raion-based mobile teams in developing 
skills  for  designing  sound  business  plans  and  farm  analysis;  and  (iv)  develop  the  production 
management strategies and crop mix options for restructured farms.

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 

The “Without Project” Scenario 

A. 
 
1. 
The Players. The major players in the cotton subsector of Tajikistan are the (i) farmers 
and  farm  workers;  (ii)  ginners;  (iii)  investors;  (iv)  exporters  and  traders;  and  (v)  local 
consumers/buyers,  mostly  spinners  and  oil  refiners.  Although  the  operations  in  the  cotton 
subsector are private sector-led, the Government still plays a key role at strategic points of the 
supply chain. The major players in the Government are: (i) the central government, which sets 
annual production targets and allocates these among the  raions (districts); (ii) the rais (district 
governor), who ensures that production targets are met by requiring farmers to cultivate cotton 
in  at  least  70%  of  their  farmland,  and  restricting  movement  of  cotton  through  its  one-gin  and 
one-investor policy; (iii) Tajikstandard, which certifies the cotton quality in coordination with the 
gin  laboratories;  and  (iv)  Tajikistan  Universal  Goods  Exchange  (TUGE),  which  regulates  the 
pricing for fiber cotton and for inputs used in cotton production. 
 
2. 
The  bulk  of  baled  fiber  cotton  produced  in  Tajikistan  (about  85%)  is  exported.  The 
balance is sold to domestic spinning and textile industries. The value of fiber cotton comprises 
about  70%  of  the  value1 of  seed  cotton.  By-products—mainly  oil,  cake,  meal,  and  linters—
comprise about 30% of the value of seed cotton and are consumed locally.  
 
Value  Chain  for  Cotton. Figure A11.1 shows the value chain of Tajikistan cotton, and 
3. 
the relations of the various players. Vertical integration in the supply value chain is essentially 
investor-driven.  The  majority  of  these  investors  plays  many  roles—input  supplier  through  crop 
financing  with  the  farmer,  gin  owners  or  major  stockholders  of  gins,  and  local  traders  and 
exporters.

Appendix 11 

4. 
Figure  A11.2  illustrates  the  numerous  points  along  the  value  chain  where  losses  in 
volume or price (as shown by the double bar boxes) reduce the total margin and overall value of 
fiber  cotton and  by-products.  The  first  incremental  loss  in  the  value  chain  is  the  lower  yield  of 
the  farmers  because  they  have  no  incentive  to  become  more  productive  or  innovative  in  their 
use  of  land.  In  2005,  the  yield  averaged  1.55  ton  per  ha  (tph),  which  is  far  below  the  yield 
potential of 2.80 tph that would result in normal returns to farmers.2  
 
5. 
Farmers’ losses increase at the gin level. It is estimated that under-weighing of farmers' 
seed cotton at the gin door results in volume losses of about 2%. There is also theft and under-
weighing of baled fiber cotton and cotton by-products in cotton gins, estimated at 6–8% of the 
seed cotton weight. An additional discount on seed cotton is charged by gin owners for moisture 
content of the seed cotton, which is about 1.5% of the seed cotton yield.  
 
Aside  from  under-weighing  the  seed  cotton,  gin  owners  buy  the  farmers’  produce  at  a 
6. 
price that is well below its real market value. Gin owners effectively discount the price paid for 
raw cotton by as much as 10%. This is a form of subsidy to the gins for their low outturn ratio 
(less than 32% versus 36–40% of other cotton producing countries). An additional 5% is again 
deducted  from  the  farm  gate  price  because  of  the  long  ginning  processing  time  (200  days  as 
opposed to the normal 90 days for processing time). Moreover, many gin owners do not return 
all of the by-products of seed cotton to the farmers, thus depriving them of the revenue they are 
due for their seed cotton.   
 
The pricing of fiber cotton is also under-valued through the pricing formula3 that is set by 
7. 
TUGE.  In  this  formula,  international  buyers  are  offered  a  5%  discount  on  the  purchase  of 
Tajikistan cotton based on the price of second-grade fiber cotton and not on the actual quality of 
the baled fiber cotton. The standardized second grade classing of the fiber cotton quality applied 
by TUGE in the pricing formula is because of the inadequacy of the current cotton classification 
system. The flawed grading system of fiber cotton reduces the price of Tajik fiber cotton by as 
much  as  8–10%.  It  is  estimated  that  the  current  classification  system  results  in  losses  of 
revenue  to  the  cotton  subsector  of  as  much  as  $13  million  per  annum.  Foreign  merchants 
under-weigh the baled cotton that is shipped for export to lower their tax costs. This costs the 
Government about $2 million per annum in tax revenue.4 
 
 
The  overall  leakage  in  the  value  chain  of  the  cotton  subsector,  in  terms  of  volume  of 
8. 
seed cotton from the farm production level up to the export and local buyer destination, amounts 
to about 656 kilograms per hectare (kg/ha), or 189,600 ton (t) per year. Of this foregone seed 
cotton amount, about 60% is due to the inefficient use and allocation of inputs arising from the 
asymmetric implementation of the production contract arrangements. In terms of foregone fiber 
cotton at a 32% gin outturn, the volume loss for the country is about 56,000 t per year. At the 
current free on board (FOB) price, the foregone opportunity costs to the subsector in terms of 
fiber cotton earnings are about $75 million. The incremental additional loss because of low gin 
outturns  (presently  at  32%  outturn),  ranges  from  $11  million  (if  the  outturn  would  increase  to 
34%) to $21 million (if the outturn is at 36%). These values still exclude the returns from the by-
products.

The “With Project” Scenario 

B. 
 
9. 
Financial Benefit. The main differences in the value chain’s post-farm sections between 
the  “with”  and  ”without”  project  scenarios  are  the  following:  (i)  the  processing  outturn  at 
ginneries increases on average from 32.0% to 35.2% (i.e., there is an effective 10.0% increase 
in  processing  efficiency);  (ii)  the  discounted  yield  of  2.0%  by  volume  of  seed  cotton  between 
farm and ginnery is eliminated; (iii) the discounted yield of 1.5% for moisture content between 
farm and ginnery is eliminated; (iv) the additional cost for farmers of the extended credit period 
equivalent to 5.0% of the ginnery door value of seed cotton is eliminated; (v) the short payment 
for fiber cotton and by-products, estimated to be 7.0% of the ginnery door value of seed cotton, 
is eliminated; (vi) the 5.0% discount offered to international buyers of fiber cotton is eliminated; 
and (vii) the 10.0% loss due to the inadequate grading system is removed. Table A11 reflects 
these changes.

75% in the returns for farms, a decrease from 16% to 6% for processors, and the Government’s 
share will remain at 18%.

representative of “other crops”) show the combined impacts of the various project interventions 
on  the  farms  selected  for  targeted  assistance  in  the  four  selected  raions.  In  addition  to  the 
improvement in the farm gate price for seed cotton, the Project is expected to increase on-farm 
cotton  yields  from  1.8  t/ha  to  2.4  t/ha,  and  allow  a  more  profitable  cropping  pattern  for  the 
selected farms. 
 
13. 
It  is  assumed  that,  as  a  consequence  of  the  Project,  there  is  no  change  in  the  net 
revenue  per  ha  for  wheat  and  other  crops.  However,  because  of  the  improved  net  financial 
returns for cotton and the change in the cropping pattern with the Project, the weighted average 
net revenue per ha increases from –$72 to $219—an increase of $147 per ha in net revenue. 
On the basis of the 15,714 ha covered by the full project interventions, the increase in net farm 
income at full project benefits is $4.6 million per annum.  
 
14. 
These farm level financial analysis results are conservative in that the analysis includes 
only benefits related to the production of 11,000 ha of cotton in the project area. However, the 
cotton  market  development  initiatives  of  the  Project  will  have  beneficial  impacts  on  the  prices 
received by farms for seed cotton beyond the immediate project area. On the basis of 448,000 t 
of seed cotton produced in 2005, the increase in price received by farmers as a consequence of 
the Project implies an increase in total farm income of $52 million per annum.  
 
Economic  Impact.  The  economic  analysis  has  been  undertaken  in  terms  of  the 
15. 
domestic price numeraire in 2006 constant prices, and a shadow exchange rate factor of 1.117 
was applied to the internationally traded component of costs and benefits. Economic prices for 
seed cotton for the without and with the Project scenarios have been estimated based on similar 
calculations  as  for  the  financial  price  estimates.  However,  a  number  of  transformations  have 
been undertaken to convert from financial to economic prices.  
 
16. 
Economic crop budgets with and without the Project have been prepared. An economic 
life  of  30  years  from  2007  to  2036  has  been  assumed,  and  no  residual  value  of  benefits  has 
been assumed at the end of this period, even though the benefits should continue indefinitely. 
Zero benefits in year 1 (2007) of the Project have been assumed, one third of full project annual 
benefits in year 2 (2008), two thirds in year 2 (2009), and full project annual benefits from year 4 
(2010) onwards. 
 
17. 
The economic price for seed cotton increases from $330/t without the Project to $430/t 
with  the  Project—an  increase  of  30%.  The  base  case  economic  analysis  gives  an  economic 
internal rate of return (EIRR) of 28.7%. Sensitivity testing indicates that the EIRR remains above 
20% with a reduction of 10% in the average cotton yield achieved with the Project (i.e., the yield

Appendix 12 

59

 

SUMMARY OF ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW 

Environmental Review and Implications on Project Intervention  

 
The Project is expected to produce no environmental impact as it will not (i) involve any 
1. 
major construction that requires resettlement or land acquisition; (ii) invest in the construction of 
dams,  new  canals,  or  head-works  that  would  allow  increased  water  abstraction  from  main 
sources;  (iii)  enlarge  the  land  area  planted  to  cotton;  and  (iv)  will  not  increase  the  use  of 
pesticides.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  classifies  the  project  as  category  C,  which 
requires  environmental  review  from  the  sector  perspective.  Below  is  a  summary  of  the 
environmental review. The full review is in Supplementary Appendix K.  
 
A. 
 
2. 
Efficiency  of  Water  Use.  In  Tajikistan,  the  most  pressing  environmental  problem  of 
agricultural  production  is  land  degradation.  This  is  due  mainly  to  erosion,  salinization, 
waterlogging,  and  desertification.  Soil  fertility  has  also  been  considerably  reduced  because  of 
pesticide  contamination  and  runoff  of  nutrients  from  agricultural  fields.  Since  cotton  is  the 
predominant  crop  on  irrigated  lands,  its  cultivation  is  at  the  core  of  environmental  concerns  in 
Tajikistan’s agriculture. 
 
3. 
Tajikistan's  irrigated  areas  are  devoted  to  cotton  (which  accounts  for more  than  half  of 
the value of crop production), grain, fodder, potatoes, vegetables, melons, vineyards, and fruit 
trees. About 85% of the irrigated land is found in Khatlon and Sughd, Tajikistan’s major cotton 
growing regions.  
 
4. 
The  partial  breakdown  of  Tajikistan’s  irrigation  system  is  among  the  reasons  for  the 
steady  decline  of  the  cotton  yields. Water  is  not  delivered  to dehkan  (small-sized individual  or 
family-owned farms with land use rights) farms on time and in the required quantities. The state 
of  the  drainage  infrastructure  is  even  in  worse  condition  than  the  irrigation  infrastructure.  This 
results in high water tables, waterlogging, and salinity of the soil. In turn, poor drainage in the 
farms  leads  to  wasteful  use  of  water.  It  is  estimated  that  115,000  ha  of  the  arable  land  in 
Tajikistan1 is adversely affected by excessive use of water. 
 
The  average  irrigation  efficiency  at  the  farm  level  in  Tajikistan  is  28%.2 Studies  have 
5. 
shown that water application can be reduced to at least a third of current levels, and actual water 
use can be reduced from the present high-usage level of 15,000 cubic meters (m3) to 5,000 m3. 
However,  for  this  to  happen,  a  combination  of  the  following  measures  are  required: 
(i) rehabilitation  of  irrigation  and  drainage  facilities,  (ii)  regular  operation  and  maintenance  of 
these facilities, (iii) the use of land-leveling technologies and improved agronomic practices, and 
(iv) a more level playing field and market environment for the cotton supply chain.3  
 
6. 
The  Project  aims  to  improve  economic  returns  accruing  to  cotton  farmers  and  farm 
workers  through  the  following  measures:  (i)  farm  debt  resolution  in  four  raions  (district 
government), (ii) access to alternative financing for restructured farms, (iii) policy reform to give 
farmers  more  freedom  to  decide  their  farm  and  processing  activities,  and  (iv)  policy  reform  to 
ensure  better  pricing  for  fiber  cotton  through  the  adoption  and  implementation  of  a  universal 
cotton grading standards (UCGS) as well as the development of bonded warehouses. Together 
with  farm  reorganization,  these  measures  will  give  farmers  a  stronger  incentive  to  produce 
efficiently  and  to  cost  effectively  the  use  of  their  inputs,  including  irrigation  water.  In  addition, 
various  donor  organizations  are  assisting  farmers  to  organize  themselves  into  water  users’ 
associations  that  can  introduce  cost  recovery  mechanisms.  The  total  effect  of  these  reform

 60 

 

Appendix 12 

measures will be significant in terms of lowering water consumption. Experts estimate that in the 
case  of  cotton,  wheat,  and  corn  planted  in  the  driest  areas  of  Tajikistan,  the  irrigation  water 
consumption  could  be  reduced  from  the  present  average  as  follows:  from  12,000  m3/ha  to 
8,000 m3/ha  for  cotton;  from  10,000  m3/ha  to  3,000  m3/ha  for  wheat;  and  from  9,100  m3/ha  to 
7,600 m3/ha for corn.  
 
Reduction of seepage losses from main canals and oversupply of irrigation will also have 
7. 
a  beneficial  effect  on  farms  in  terms  of  a  lower  water  table,  lower  risk  of  salinity,  and  fewer 
stagnant water pools in settlements that can cause health problems.  
 
Implications  from  Pesticide  Use.  Although  Tajikistan  took  the  lead  in  biological  crop 
8. 
pest  control  during  the  Soviet  era,  its  pest  control  practice  at  present  relies  heavily  on 
chemicals.  The  biocontrol  facilities  that  used  to  supply  beneficial  insects  to  the  farms  are  no 
longer  operational.  Based  on  studies  and  field  visits,  farms  now  intensively  use  pest  control 
chemicals, particularly in the lower valleys that practice cotton monoculture.  
 
9. 
There  are  anecdotal  reports  of  the  continued  use  of  harmful  levels  of  toxic  pesticides, 
herbicides, and defoliants throughout Tajikistan because of the country’s heavy use of chemical 
pest  control  methods  before  the  1990s.  However,  inadequate  monitoring  makes  it  difficult  to 
determine the magnitude of the problem. 
 
10. 
The findings of this review show the following to be very common in Tajikistan: (i) use of 
World  Health  Organization  Class  1  and  unregistered  chemicals  purchased  from  the  black 
market;  (ii)  inappropriate  storage  and  use  of  pesticides  and  lack  of  safety  precautions  in 
pesticide  application;  (iii) improper  disposal  of  waste  and  chemical  packaging;  (iv)  inadequate 
enforcement  of  laws  and  regulations  on  labeling  and  sales  of  agricultural  chemicals;  (v)  low 
levels  of  awareness  on  integrated  pest  management  (IPM)  among  officials,  farmers,  and 
chemical resellers and traders; and (vi) general lack of public awareness of the environmental 
and health implications of the improper use of pesticides. If IPM is not strongly advocated and 
widely  enforced  in  Tajikistan,  farm  reorganization  and  debt  resolution  may  lead  to  more 
intensive  agriculture  practices  that  use  more  of  agrochemicals  such  as  fertilizers,  pesticides, 
and herbicides. 
 
11. 
In  addition,  if  farmers  do  not  have  a  clear  understanding  of  the  need  for  the  proper 
storage,  transport,  and  application  of  pesticides  and  herbicides,  the  chemical  runoff  from  the 
fields  could  significantly  pollute  both  surface  and  ground  water  and  cause  health  problems 
among  the  populace.  Therefore,  it  is  necessary  to  promote  IPM,  particularly  in  disseminating 
knowledge  on:  (i)  managing  pests  to  keep  them  below  economically  damaging  levels; 
(ii) biological pest control techniques, increased reliance on cultural methods for weed control, 
and increased organic fertilization to reduce overall use of agrochemical inputs; and (iii) the safe 
application  of  less  toxic  pesticides.  The  use  of  IPM  would  minimize  the  adverse  effects  of 
agrochemical on nontarget organisms, human health, and the biophysical environment. 
 
B. 
 
12. 
Project activities are not anticipated to have direct impacts on the environment. Instead, 
they  may  have  indirect  positive  impacts  on  land  management,  water  management,  and 
pesticide management by the target dehkan farms. Only the laboratory upgrade in three sites, 
as well as the warehouse upgrades in two sites, may have potential limited direct environmental 
impact. Specifically, these activities will have: (i) short-term construction impact associated with 
minor  reconstruction  of laboratory  and  warehouse  facilities,  resulting  in  some  noise,  dust,  and 
waste  material;  (ii) short-term  minor  congestion  problems  on  construction  sites;  and 
(iii) occupational health and possible public health hazards that may be caused by the improper 
use or accidental spillage of sulfuric acid when the laboratory becomes operational. The short-
term construction impacts can be minimized by making it mandatory for the contractor to follow

best practices in construction, waste minimization and disposal, and traffic control. The risk of 
accidental spillage of sulfuric acid can be mitigated by requiring the contractor implementing this 
project  component  to  observe  internationally  and  nationally  recognized  environmental  health 
and  safety  procedures.  The  contractor  will  also  be  required  to  provide  training,  especially  for

13. 
The  Project  may  also  prevent  possible  indirect  negative  impacts  on  the  environment 
related to (i) water use (such as waterlogging and salinization); (ii) pesticide use (particularly in 
the  use  of  unregistered  chemicals, 
inadequate 
enforcement  of  laws  on  labeling  and  sales  of  agrochemicals,  and  nonobservance  of  the  IPM 
system);  and  (iii)  land  use  by  the  target  farms  (soil  erosion,  improper  use  of  fertilizers  and 
agrochemicals, and ineffective irrigation and drainage systems). The potential indirect negative 
impacts on the environment can be mitigated by the following activities: (i) awareness programs 
on  sustainable  practices  on  water,  pesticides  and  IPM,  and  land  use;  (ii)  experience-sharing 
between the Project’s target farms with dehkan farms and members of successful water users’ 
associations  on  modem  irrigation  and  drainage  systems  as  well  as  on-farm  water  and  land 
management 
land  productivity); 
(iii) development of appropriate regulations to enforce proper labeling, sales, handling, and safe 
disposal  of  agricultural  chemicals.  This  will  be  undertaken  to  support  the  Persistent  Organic 
Pollutants  (POPs)  unit  within  the  State  Committee  for  Environmental  Protection  and  Forestry 
and other relevant government agencies; and (iv) requesting commercial banks to put in place 
procedures  that  will  ensure  proper  consideration  and  review  of  the  possible  environmental 
consequences of proposed activities.   
 
14. 
ADB  has  recently  approved  a  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA)  on  Partnership  on 
Persistent Organic Pollutants Pesticides Management for Agricultural Production in Central Asia 
and  Caucasus  Countries.4 The  RETA  will  focus  on  IPM  adoption,  especially  in  cotton  growing 
areas. Tajikistan will be one of the participating countries that will benefit from the technical and 
capacity  building  measures  of  the  RETA.  These  measures  are  designed  to  promote 
environment-friendly  alternative  pest  control  practices  in  cotton  production,  and  identify  a 
sustainable  funding  mechanism  for  the  cleanup  and  management  of  sites  contaminated  with 
persistent organic pollutant pesticides.  
 
Conclusions 
C. 
 
 
15. 
Based  on  ADB’s  environmental  requirements  as  well  as  Tajikistan’s  environmental 
legislation currently in force, the Project does not require any environmental impact assessment 
or  other  environmental  review  of  any  potential  negative  impacts.  However,  as  soon  as  the 
Project is approved, it would be advisable to consult with the State Committee for Environmental 
Protection and Forestry and obtain further guidance on compliance requirements with the State 
Ecological Expertise. This is considering the fact that Tajikistan's environmental legislation lacks 
an  environmental  impact  assessment  categorization  system  and  that  the  State  Committee  for 
Environmental  Protection  and  Forestry  decides  on  environmental 
impact  assessment 
procedures on a case-to-case basis.
